The smallest laptop I'd had before this was a 15" Macbook Pro (MBP). After 4 years of rough use, it has a cracked screen and a battery that needs replacing. After I got glass in my hand from opening the screen, I realized it was time for something new. While the Macbook Pro probably booted in 30 seconds or so when it was new, it now takes a minimum of 45 seconds, usually more like 1 minute. It got hot when I had more than 3 or 4 apps open (albeit high energy consuming apps), and the battery life quickly eroded from about 4.5-5 hour charge to 2 hours max if I kept the screen brightness at one notch.

Enter the Chromebook: the screen is not big, but its big enough. It isn't particularly fast, but its plenty fast enough. The screen is the perfect size for this computer: it is meant as something portable, easy to carry, and easy to search the web or edit a document. Its great for my because if I start feeling lazy, it really isn't what you want to watch a movie on, only because the screen is big (although the resolution is still very nice, I checked it out).

It definitely only has 2gb of ram, and if you have a nicer computer, you'll notice the very brief lag. My desktop has 32gb of ram and flawlessly switches between web pages, applications, etc. With the Chromebook, you will occasionally see a 0.25-0.50 second  lag, but its nothing that impinges functionality. On occasion, I can type ahead of it, but again only by fractions of a second before it catches up and keeps up to my pace. When watching netflix or youtube videos, you may get a stuck image, but it is quick to catch up and move along (this is on 100MB/s wifi, so it wasn't the internet connection that was the problem).

The front camera is plenty sufficient. Video chatting is easy and the microphone is good. The downward facing speakers are.. strange, but they do still provide plenty of sound. I have no intention of this computer serving as a speaker - anywhere I use this, I'll have headphones in, so speakers don't really plan much of a role for me.

The battery life is similarly outstanding. On the Macbook Pro, I was always annoyed that the lowest backlight setting was still way too bright. It would hurt your eyes at night and was just generally annoying. The Samsung Chromebook dims down much much further, and still has about the same brightness as a MBP on full brightness. This is nice because when I'm sitting in a dim room, I can practically put this on one of the lowest brightness settings and battery life is outstanding. Similarly, the extremely quick start up means that once you finish working and need to leave, you can shut down the computer and preserve battery life. After using the computer for 4 1.5 hour segments, I currently have an estimated 2 hours of battery life remaining. For my MBP, I would have need to recharge at least once already, and I'd probably be on the verge of dying again.

The only downsides I can mention: one is obvious, it is limited. If you need frequent access to Photoshop or another application, it will get tiresome connecting via Remote Desktop all the time. The speaker is not great, but honestly its fine and for a $240 laptop that does everything I've asked it to, I'm glad Samsung realized that laptop speakers are used sparingly and aren't an important feature. Last, the blacks aren't deep. If you want deep blacks, plug into the convenient HDMI cable on the back of the laptop and connect to HDTV :)

Also, I'm 6'4 with pretty large hands and I was worried about the keyboard being too small. This has not been my experience - the keys are about the same size as any keyboard, but a lot of the periphery keys have been removed so you just have the letters, numbers, three buttons on the right, four on the left, and a row of specialized buttons at the very top. The track pad size is cut down, but still very usable (although I plan to keep a mouse because I don't generally like trackpads). The track pad is not as good as the MBP I had, but its good enough.

Build quality seems good. The casing fits tight and is secured by nice, big screws, not the tiny ones that break and fall, never to be seen again. The screen stays firmly shut when closed. When I close it and the screen is about 2 inches from closed, I feel the spring-loaded action force the screen closed. This is a feature I do not notice on any Dell laptop I've ever used, or Mac product really. Its laid out simply and efficiently, just like it performs. It is very light and very portable.

Final verdict: If you can work with Google Drive and Chrome all day, this product provides premium value given its very low cost. Its hard to believe this sells for less than a smart phone or tablet with all it is able to do.

I had, what the kids call, a first-world problem. I wanted a device I could surf the internet with while watching TV in the evenings. It needed to be something small (but not too small) and light that I could quickly grab without a big production of power adapters and laptop trays. My Samsung Galaxy Note 3 smartphone is too small to comfortably surf with for more than a few minutes. My Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 2012 tablet has a terrible screen, and the on-screen keyboard is an exercise in masochism (I considered upgrading to a new 2014 model with the better screen, but I would still have the keyboard problem). My MSi GT70 laptop is too big and only lasts for about an hour without being plugged in because it's technically a gaming laptop. What's a spoiled American with a disposable income and no kids to do? I tried a Chromebook.

POSITIVES
+ KEYBOARD!!! No more uncomfortable, imprecise touch-screen keyboards like on my tablet. This Chromebook's keyboard is comfortable. I also love the direct, hard shortcut keys for screen brightness, volume, etc. without having to shift with a Fn or Ctrl key.
+ The mouse pad works very well, and the Chrome OS has an awesome function where a single tap with one finger is a left-click, and a single tap with two fingers is a right-click. GENIUS! Why has no one else thought of this before?!
+ Great battery life, so far, and the system recharges very quickly.
+ The system, itself, is very small and very thin, and perfect for quickly picking up on the go or storing in a nook.
+ The OS and interface are very straightforward and easy to use, and the two most important applications (Chrome and Gmail) are pre-installed. Just log in with your Gmail account and your email and all of your bookmarks appear magically (well, not technically magic, but something similar). Even though this is not a Windows OS, many of the shortcuts still exist (i.e., Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V, etc.).
+ Far less expensive than a tablet, and will provide much of the same benefits, plus a real keyboard.

NEGATIVES
- Screen resolution could be a bit better (1366x768). It's a little tough to go from 1920x1080 all day on my PCs, and then look at the downgraded res on the Chromebook. This is a big benefit of choosing the Galaxy Note 10.1 2014 (2560x1600), however the Note 10.1 2014 is also $300+ more expensive.
- Screen contrast isn't great. Adjusting the screen brightness helps a little, but it still has gray-ish black levels.

This review is separated into the following sections, so if you are interested in only one feel free to jump ahead to that one:
-Introduction
-Google Drive, how I use it in an Office-based school
-Computer Science
-YouTube (different from entertainment)
-Entertainment on the Chromebook
-Screen
-Battery life
-Summary

I am a ninth grader. I looked for a laptop to use at school (we have a bring-your-own-device BYOD policy at my high school) and bring to the library and work on homework. I wanted something light and portable. I have a Windows 7 machine at home, and that's what I had used for school projects. I did not have Microsoft Office installed on that computer, instead I used Google Drive. I researched what a Chromebook is and I thought about how I would use it in school. Here is how I use it:

Word / Research / Typing:
Google Drive is more than sufficient. I am in AP Human Geography, and my daily homework consists of reading sections of the chapter and writing notes (summaries). My teacher posts the reading guides in a .docx format, and I have no problems with formatting. What I do is I download the Word file to the Chromebook's internal storage, then I upload it to Drive and select "convert files to Google Docs format". PowerPoints are a little trickier.

PowerPoints:
My Biology teacher posts several PowerPoints from which we take notes. Compatibility between Google Presentations and PowerPoint is not that great yet, so I just use the web-based version of Office at SkyDrive (now branded OneDrive). Other than that, I have no problems.

Excel:
I do not regularly use the more advanced features of Excel. For school we just use data tables and Vlook up functions, nothing too fancy.

Computer Science:
I am taking Computer Science at school, and unfortunately, we are taught the Visual Basic programming language, which is only Windows-based. This is only my generation's bad luck. Next year, the freshmen will learn C++
I plan on taking AP Computer Science in a couple of years, though, and they use Java, so there will not be any problems with Chromebook compatibility.

YouTube:
I put this under a different section than entertainment because I am a YouTuber, so it is not just video-watching, but production and editing. If you plan on using a Chromebook for these purposes, this is not the computer for you. For video editing, I need to use my Windows machine or the Macs at my school.

Entertainment:
For games, the Chromebook is pretty limited; You will not be using this to play Minecraft or League of Legends or anything. You can use Netflix, YouTube, Hulu, and any other online video services. I purchased a cheap HDMI cable to connect to my family's TV, and we all watch shows together. Just keep the brightness down and this is great. Sort of like a make-shift Chromecast replacement. YouTube works great, I can watch 1080p video no problem.

Screen:
The screen on the Chromebook is a little dim, it is matte, so it will not be reflecting the light around you. I primarily use it indoors, so it is usually great. It will not blow you away, but for the price it is great.

Battery life:
Arguably the best feature on this computer. With 50% brightness, I can easily squeeze about 7 hours of battery life, as long as I am not multitasking, e.g. listening to music on the background. On full brightness, probably around 5 and a half hours.

Summary:
Does this replace your primary computer? Depends. Some things like printing are still not as clear and easy as they should be. For a student, this is great. It is incredibly fast, prevents me from getting distracted with all the bells and whistles from my primary Windows machine, and is super light and portable. I would definitely recommend this to any of you. Please make sure you do your research, if you have any questions leave them down below, I will answer them.

Update Feb 25, 2014. I (grudgingly) raised this to 3 stars. There are a few reasons where this system is actually the best system for some people. Read my Feb. 25, 2014, Update at the bottom.

In the 1960s and 1970s, the government and corporations used a central mainframe computer with lots of dumb terminals hooked into it. The terminal was a monitor and keyboard, but no processing ability. They could send and receive messages from other terminals or the mainframe. Printouts were done via the mainframe. When the mainframe was down, the terminal was dead.

This chrome system works much the same way. The computer must be hooked into the Internet to be functional. Printouts are done by printers which are connected to the Internet. There is only a handful of things that you can do with the Chrome Operating System if it is not hooked into the Internet.

While hooked into the Internet, it can do about 80% of the things that a normal computer can do.

One really down side is that most of the apps and functions revolve around around cloud storage. Google provides limited (100 GB) of storage for 2 years. After that you have to pay a rental fee. Or you can use other cloud storage systems.

The Chromebook supports external hard drives, but many of the available apps don't support hard drives. Everything is geared towards putting everything that you have onto an Internet Cloud Drive.

Also, not all video formats are supported. I have a bunch of AVI videos from a travel camera. I can't play any of them without uploading them to a cloud and converting them to another format while they reside on the cloud drive. However, MOV files from my DSLR play fine straight from the memory card.

As I stated above, all of the power of it's apps is derived from the Internet. It is basically a paperweight when offline, with the exception of a handful of games. It's only redeeming quality is it's online ability, which is why I gave it 2 stars. I consider it a waste of money and don't intend to buy another one of these.

Update Feb. 25, 2014

I raised my rating for this Chromebook to 3 stars for a few reasons:

  1.) It starts up extremely fast as compared to any other computer systems.
  2.) The Chrome web browser seems to work better and faster on here then on either Windows or Linux.
  3.) There is an advantage to using programs residing on the Internet in that they are always up to date and all related files are available to them.
  4.) I can think of a few non-computer-literate people whom this computer would be perfect for. (They just wish to send/receive email, check Facebook, check the news and weather, watch some TV or movies, check to see what is on sale, and they can't seem to mess this computer up (yet). This is the perfect computer for them...)
  5.) Virus protection does not seem to be a problem with this system.

Please understand that any Application that requires all commands and actions to be sent over the Internet will be slower then an Application residing on your hard drive. This will really become apparent with large files like creating movies.

I am a full time pre-med student who also works full time. Weekends aside, in any given day I have 1-3 hours outside of my school-work-sleep cycle to study for exams, meet other students for group projects, and generally try to stay ahead of the curve in a very competitive, science-heavy curriculum.

I bought the chromebook to help me keep everything organized. I frequently found myself in need of a small computer I could use to review notes, check grades, and turn in student assignments. The chromebook does that trick very well. I bought the Case Star Neoprene Laptop Notebook Sleeve (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008FU1HE0/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_2) to protect it in the messenger bag I use at school. It was quite cheap, and works great.

Pros:
 -Small, portable, most painless setup I've ever experienced. It was up and running within less than 3 minutes of plugging it in.
 -Syncs to your Gmail account automatically, including Google docs, anything on your Google drive, keeps your bookmark preferences.
 -Fairly durable. I'm pretty hard on stuff and I've definitely scuffed it up and have a tendency to leave it in sleep rather than turning it all the way off, for weeks at a time. It performs just as well now as it did the day I got it.
 -**Notetaking** is a serious breeze with the Chromebook. I have *all* of my notes, for every single class on my chromebook, which automatically syncs to my drive. (This is great because you have automatic, instantaneous access from anywhere you can log into Google.)
 -MS Excel and PowerPoint knockoffs that work pretty well. I've given in-class presentations with these softwares.
 -Probably not news to anyone, but it reads PDFs, Excel docs, .docx files perfectly well. The problem comes with editing them.
 -gdocs exports .docx, .PDF, and .rtf files flawlessly 95% of the time. (Look out for export issues in advanced editing situations like highlighting.)

Cons:
I have three gripes with the Chromebook, and three only:
 - No MS Office. This can be a real pain, and though eventually I'm sure Google will get ahead of Microsoft and work out fairly flawless conversion algorithms, the fact is, they're just not there. Converting a project that you started in the lab on Excel over to Google's spreadsheet software is functionally impossible. The data will not properly transfer and you'll be left with an unusable mess.
 -No touchscreen. I understand that asking for a touchscreen in this price segment is unreasonable, and I'd be happy to pay more for it, but it can be really frustrating to try and sketch the molecular structure of a hydrocarbon with the gdocs "Insert drawing" function using the built-in touch-pad.
 -The Bluetooth doesn't really work. Peripherals like mice and keyboards seem to function fine, but using Bluetooth headphones or a boombox is problematic. They will sync and begin working fine, but after a few minutes invariably they start skipping and it only gets worse from there. I troubleshot at length, different environments to control for interference, using multiple different devices, all from unique manufacturers, etc. Same thing no matter what. After doing some searching I learned that it is a known issue with some of the chromebooks, and that they are supposedly working on it, but with a nebulous due date on the patch. I don't expect them to ever fix it, but for me, it's not that big of a deal. I'm never far enough away from it to need Bluetooth, and my Galaxy S3 works just fine if I need some study jams.

Overall - Great experience. I would have given 5 stars if not for the Bluetooth issue, as that is the only thing they promised, but didn't deliver. My Chromebook is constantly with me, at all times, and it really shines on the note-taking front. I'm one of the few people in the university to use a laptop of any kind to take notes, and it gives me the opportunity to grab a lot more information than those who are writing. I like being able to catch the little stories each prof tells about their experiences with x concept. I find these tidbits help me put a color on those ideas and remember them better.

Tips for taking notes on the Chromebook:
 -Get familiar with the keyboard shortcuts specific to gdocs word processor. It will save you buckets of time.
 -If you have a chem-heavy curriculum try hitting Google images for molecular structures to save time. Just make sure it matches what Prof is doing on the board.
 -If you have a chem or math-heavy curriculum and need to use Greek and other letters like Sigma, Delta, or delta+/delta- frequently (thermodynamics, kinetics, intermolecular forces, etc.) make a table of all the applicable symbols and units (like kj/mol for instance) ahead of time, and paste it to the bottom of your notes before class starts. This way you can simply ctrl+c/ctrl+v (copy/paste) them into your notes without wasting time diving for them in the gdocs drop-downs.
 -Make some time after lab to rough-draft your report on campus in a computer lab. Or do it at home if you have access to MS Office. Don't waste your time trying to build lab reports unless they don't need graphs, or you and your lab partner(s) are both comfortable pulling up your gmail and running all your data in Google's spreadsheet software. (Could probably done. I'll report back if I even get a chance to try this.)
 -If you're re-writing notes in your own words for exams (which you definitely should be), rewrite them by hand. You're going to spend more time thinking about it when you have to slow down enough to physically write.

I purchased this Chromebook 2 days ago and I absolutely loved it! I am a nursing student and needed something lightweight, affordable and able to write papers on and most importantly, open up all of my documents that the teachers make available online. I did a lot of research when it came to buying this and thanks to the reviews I was able to make an excellent decision. Here are a few of the key things that I needed this to do in order to make a smart purchase from a student's perspective:

1) Affordable! After looking at all other laptops, this was seemed to give me the most bang for my buck.
2) Lightweight - This is only 2.4lbs which is essential when you are walking to and from classes.
3) Ability to write papers - although this is unable to have Microsoft Word installed on it, I have available Google Docs which is just as good, in my opinion, as Microsoft Word. A spreadsheet app is also installed and accessible on this as well.
4) Opening up required information - I was nervous at first, knowing that I couldn't install Microsoft Word, if I would be able to open up documents that were in that format. After reading a previous review, I saw that I could still open them up and after trying it out for myself... is TRUE! I am able to open up Word Docs as well as Powerpoints.
5) Keyboard - I am typing this review with this right now and I have to say, the keyboard is great. Everything is spaced adequately and offers a great typing experience. I type very fast and it hasn't slowed me down.
6) Battery life - I have read that the battery on this can last up to 8 hours which is great!

As for some cons - Although I do not watch movies online, I did check it out using my Amazon Prime account and did see that the picture quality is not all that great. But considering what I am primarily using this for, it does not impact how I rate the Samsung Chromebook.

I have yet to test out to see if my printer will work with this. I have a regular printer that plugs into the computer and also a wifi one. Will see what happens!

All in all, this was an amazing purchase and I am so happy that I bought it. I could not be any happier. For students who are looking for something affordable, lightweight and able to do school work on, this is a great buy. I am in LOVE WITH THIS! I hope this review helps anyone who is comparing their options.

I bought this unit because I thought it would be a good compromise between a tablet and fully functioning traditional laptop. And, for the price, it's a great value!

I wanted a lightweight, quick-booting machine with a full keyboard that had good battery life. That is exactly what I got. My wife uses it mainly for web browsing and media consumption and occasionally uses Google docs to work with a document or spreadsheet, etc.

Yes, there are things it can't do that a traditional laptop can. Yes, it takes a while to get used to what the Chrome OS can and can't do. Yes, there's no Skype app so you have to use Google Hangouts. Yes, you can't hook a printer up to it but have to use Google Cloudprint (you have to be signed in to the corresponding account, frustrating when you are browsing anonymously and want to print, or logged in to a different user that isn't associated with the cloudprint printer). No, it doesn't have a touchscreen, so if that's an issue, buy a tablet. But again, I wanted something in between the two form factors, and this seems to be a good fit.

And for the money, it's almost a throw away machine, in a sense. I mean, what do you expect for a couple hundred dollars? I am happy with what it has to offer.

Also it is unclear but I'm fairly certain this other computer (used to configure the printer) has to actually be on and in the house. So that is a big drawback especially since my printer is a laptop I carry with me. So the chromebook could be home and I could be out and my son won't be able to print (even if we solved the technical issue in paragraph 1).

Some say that this is only good for surfing the web but I have found it has been great for productivity - you just have to familiarize yourself with google drive. Before this computer I always used microsoft office. But I have actually come to like google docs and sheets so much more. Being connected to the cloud means never having to worry about losing a usb thumbdrive and updating your documents and spreadsheets anywhere. Not to mention google docs, sheets, and slides  work flawlessly with their microsoft counterparts - so no worries about sharing files with others.

This thing is great for travel and streams netflix wonderfully. The screen is not a beautiful retina display by any means but for my purposes it looks great and gets the job done. I actually enjoy watching netflix on my chromebook and think it looks pretty good. The speakers on this puppy are amazing though, crystal clear and loud. You could even set this up in your room to listen to music. I was very impressed with this thing's sound system. This laptop is thin and sleek and has a quality build. The keyboard and track-pad is top quality and feels great for writing long documents. Really if you are a student or a professional i would recommend this laptop any day over any other tablet - its so much easier to get work done.

There are some downsides, the keyboard is not backlit so when it's completely dark its pretty hard to see (however most people should have the keys memorized and not stare at the keys so this isn't a problem for me - home row for the win). Being so inexpensive the laptop is not metal but plastic, so it is very prone to scuffs and marks. You can't download a lot of software for this thing and downloading/managing music and other files not not the easiest. These issues don't really bother me because I was well aware of these things when I bought it. The only thing I would like to see change is for there to be a snipping function like in windows - very useful in productivity.

I must admit that I'm a bit disappointed with this computer. I don't want to have to use a web app or their clunky file manager to organize, crop, or edit my photos. I'm not even a photographer and I was annoyed with what it took to process a few pictures (just regular jpegs, not RAW images or anything fancy).

The processor certainly leaves something to be had. Granted, you can't expect blazing fast technology for this dirt cheap, but you would think that the stripped down chromebooks without a complicated OS to juggle would be able to perform the same as a regular laptop. First off - I knew what I was getting when I ordered this thing. I knew it wasn't an Alienware gaming laptop with the best processor, most RAM, and biggest HD. This is an app-driven, cloud-based operating system which is fast, sleek, and very well put together. That being said, here's my review.

I got this fast as ever from Amazon (Thanks Prime). Unboxing wasn't spectacular, but hey, who cares really. It didn't start when I first picked it up, but when I plugged it in, it started right away, and the battery had about 75% charge. I thought it was weird it didn't start up immediately but no big deal.

Battery Life: Amazing! This thing really does last 6.5 hours on a charge (a full charge is just over an hour) which is pretty spectacular for a laptop these days.

Screen: It's slightly lackluster. The resolution is good, but it just doesn't have that 'pop' that most of the expensive laptops have these days. There's also an angle 'issue' that if you're not at the right viewing angle, it's a bit hard to see it, but hey, that's why it opens more...

OS: I love the Chrome operating system, and I use the browser on my desktop. It's great having everything the same when you go to another computer. It's fast, responsive, and works well. I haven't had an issue yet.

Keyboard: I really like it. I'm kind of picky about laptop keyboards so I don't like most, but this one feels good, although not top of the line. I'm a big guy with larger hands, but they fit nicely on the keyboard without any problems.

Wifi: This works great, and was easy to connect.

Webcam: This is probably the worst part of the product. With technology the way it is, there's no reason there can't be a webcam that doesn't lag and have bad lighting like this one does. I haven't used it much, but I don't see it as a great means of communication as it's not good quality and could be frustrating to another used trying to see me.

Each purchase comes with a free 100GB of could storage from Amazon which is more than anyone should need. I don't have problems saving things to the cloud, as it's easy to do and keeps the computer itself from getting bogged down like older ones seem to do. There is a slight learning curve for this thing as it isn't Windows, but if you know your way around a computer this is not a problem.

Overall I love this thing and I'm glad I finally got it. The plastic is a bit cheap feeling, but for under $300 after taxes and shipping it's well worth it! If you're looking for a piece of equipment for younger kids, students, or just for browsing the internet or working on documents, this is the best option out there!

I used it for the first 6, and then passed it to my son when I purchased an Acer C720.  We have had absolutely no problems with the Samsung, and it has been fun watching Chrome OS evolve and improve over time.  The Chromebooks have shown me that I really don't need an expensive Windows machine for my home computing needs.  In fact, within a month of owning this computer I had totally abandoned my Windows laptop.  We use the Chromebooks for all manner of web surfing, Netflix, Hulu Plus, Amazon Instant Video, chatting and video calls with Hangouts, creating, editing, and printing documents with Google Docs,  listening to music with Google Play, and Im even going to use a Chromebook for my taxes this year.  Even though some of the next generation Chromebooks are offering improved speed and longer battery life, this little machine is still an excellent choice for many users.  I also believe that this Chromebook will be remembered as the first affordable Chrome OS device that really brought Chrome computing to the masses.

I'll lay out pros and cons. Remember, I'm reviewing this as a graduate student. If you plan on substituting for a PC or Mac, I caution you to understand it doesn't replace those.

Pros:
Lightweight. Can carry anywhere; less than 3 lbs. is insanely small and easy to fit in a bookbag.
Google Chrome OS. Apparently this means no viruses, which is great. Runs smoothly since you're only using the internet (mostly.) Interface is good and everything loads fast.
Google Drive. I love drive for group projects and writing notes. Also for reading PDFs and organizing files. It's almost like Office... almost.
Comfortable design. Typing on this thing is a breeze. The screen is small but definitely easy to see and read. It's great for watching netflix or reading a book since you can just plop it on your lap while lying down.

Cons:
No Office. Google Drive is not office. This means that editing something here is not going to download to your PC or Mac the same. Although some times it does, especially in PDF format, and Google seems to be working on an Office Beta prototype. Still, Office is the best around. Drive is great, though, don't get me wrong on that.
Everything is connected to the internet. This means that when you listen to spotify, you can only do so if connected (no saved files.) Also, basically everything ceases to function without the internet. Put it this way: without internet, this thing doesn't work.

Aside from the cons, this is an excellent machine. Where do you go nowadays that doesn't have internet? People use their laptops at home and starbucks, on campus and in libraries. All have wifi. For the price, it's worth it, especially if you're in college. For anyone not in college, it's great if your laptop breaks, you need a second machine, or if you just want to go online and watch movies/listen to music.

Highly recommend!

I've used Windows products nearly my entire life and have grown tired of the OS BS so when I saw Samsung, a company I trust, had a netbook with Chrome OS, I decided to try it out since I was already using Chrome web browser on my Windows 8 laptop because I hate IE and Firefox was pissing me off.

Pros:
(1) Google Docs/Drive - I use this feature all the time, and love how I don't have to worry about the hard drive crashing and taking all my hard work with it. Yes, backing it up is the name of the game with Windows, and something I do religiously, but there are always exceptions (one time both my hard drive and the external drive I had went kaput around the same time, causing me to lose a year's worth of docs). Now, I don't have to worry because not only is it in the cloud, it's also accessible anywhere I go on any computer. On the netbook, it's own app located on the taskbar so really easy to just click and start writing without any hassle of looking for it.
(2) Search. This is something that not everyone will like because of how we've been trained, but the left enter button was changed into a search button, so whenever you hit it, a search box with apps menu pops up. It doesn't bother me because I"m right handed and hit the right enter key with my pinky, but it might take some getting used to for lefties or people who use that particular button.
(3) Chrome. I'm a big fan of this web browser already, so the ease of access just makes it even better for me. I have two separate Gmail accounts, and use both on the Chromebook., As a result, I have two different sets of apps and uses, much like Windows user accounts.
(4) Battery life. My laptop is an Acer with only 4 hours of battery life, so I always have to carry a charger with me and hope I'm near a convenient socket to plug in. So far with this Chromebook, I've gone at least 8 hours with heavy use (I run an e-commerce store so I'm online constantly) and don't need to worry about the charge until I get home.
(5) Browsing. I won't lie, this isn't the fastest I've ever used, but it works for what I need. Right now I have about 25 tabs open in 3 windows and haven't had any problems switching between them.

Cons:
(1) The keyboard. Now, this isn't really a big deal for me since I have small hands, but I know my boyfriend has problems typing on it, and I miss the side number keys.
(2) Chromecast casting tab. Again, not a huge problem, but quality does suffer when I'm watching Amazon Prime shows while having a bunch of tabs open. (This only applies to people who own Chromecast so skip if you have no idea what I'm talking about).
(3) Mouse. I've never liked touch pads and have always used wireless mice with my laptops. This time, however, I have opted to learn how to use it and for the most part I've learned to work with it, though I would recommend watching the tutorial or reading through the instructions to get full use out of it. Maybe with more practice this will turn from a con into a pro.

I've only had this for a little over a week, so I haven't found more cons, but so far I really love this netbook because it does what I need it to do and gets it done with less hassle than Windows at a better price than even budget laptops. Is this Chromebook for everyone? No way, but it's definitely a great option for those who don't need the full array of a laptop and just want an easy way to browse.

I've had my Chromebook since May 2013. I wanted to wait until I'd had it awhile to write a review. While I do wish it had more than one standard USB port, the webcam isn't the greatest and of all things, I sometimes miss the delete key but overall, I really like this computer. I use it a lot, take it everywhere and have rarely had any trouble with it and what trouble I've had has never been anything that couldn't be solved by closing some tabs or, at the most, restarting it. It has no problem picking up wi-fi signals most anywhere I am and that's been really helpful, much more so than trying to work on my phone.

It's incredibly light and compact. As others have said because it has a solid state hard drive, there's no fan, so it's also incredibly quiet and while it does get warm during extended use, even if I'm using it all day, it never gets as hot as previous laptops did after even short periods of use. It keeps my lap about as warm as the average house cat, as opposed to burning my legs after twenty minutes.

I frequently watch Netflix on my Chromebook. It keeps up, even if I have other tabs open. Usually, if anything goes wrong, it's Netflix and not the Chromebook. I've notice YouTube will occasionally get glitchy if I try to multitask while watching a video. The same can be said of Bandcamp but as far as streaming music from my Google Drive while typing or doing research, it usually works without any trouble. That said, the cloud storage aspect took some getting used to. I've learned to use the Scratchpad (Chrome OS equivalent of WordPad in Windows) rather than Google Docs to get my ideas out, so that I can access stuff even if I don't have internet and then when things are closer to being finalized, I use Docs to format everything and do my final drafts. With Sync, it uploads my Scratchpad files to my drive, so I can access them from my phone and other computers, as well.

The app system is pretty good. I've yet to pay for an app and I have been able to find most anything I could need and install it quickly. There are lots of similar apps, so sometimes it's a matter of trying two or three and seeing which suits my needs. Some run internally, others open in the browser and connect online. Some of the latter can take awhile to load. It's not dissimilar to Android in that way. For all I know about computers and smartphones, it could be exactly the same.

If anyone has any questions, I'd be happy to do my best to answer them. I really want to thank everyone who reviewed their Chromebook here because I read so many reviews before I decide to buy one and they really helped me make up my mind. I'm very glad I purchased this.

So I bought this laptop out of curiosity for the Chrome OS, but I was pretty sure I wouldn't find much use for it in my everyday work (I'm a developer using almost exclusively open source tools and languages).

However, I soon found out that the Samsung Chromebook does allow you to go into so-called "developer mode", where you can install a version of Linux that runs side to side with Chrome OS, kind of like a virtualization system. The piece of code that allows you to do this is called "Crouton", and is freely available from a GitHub repository with a very simple set of installation instructions included. It is developed mainly by a guy from Google, and it's been getting quite a bit of traction lately.

After installing a version of Ubuntu using Crouton, along with the XFCE desktop, I was very surprised at the overall responsiveness of the system, as well as at how easy it is to switch from Ubuntu to Crome OS with a simple keyboard shortcut.
Granted, there are some things that still need some more work (e.g. playing videos and flash support out of the box), but given how easy it is to switch from one OS to the other (videos and flash are totally supported in Chrome OS), it's not really a deal breaker for me. I was not really expecting this from such a cheap laptop.

In terms of the hardware, I found the keyboard comparable in quality to the ones in recent models of the MacBook Air. The laptop itself, as you can see in the pictures, is pretty slim and lightweight, something I appreciate since I hate carrying around heavy laptops. The touchpad quality is good, but I do miss the support for a full range of gestures found in Apple's computers. One thing I do wish this laptop had is a larger SSD. 16 GB of storage means you will need to keep a lot of your data in an external drive (it's true Google does give you 100GB of free cloud storage for two years, but unless you have a really fast Internet connection, this is no replacement for a hard drive if you're moving around large files). Again, not a deal breaker for me, but something to keep in mind.

Overall, it turned out to be an excellent laptop for me once I installed Crouton (and Ubuntu) on it.

I am a heavy weight user of all things Google, but to migrate to a Chromebook from a regular laptop is still a big step for someone who has been heavily into IT/programming/heavy software use for many years. It was a step that I wanted to take because I now do everything in the cloud, and have an Android phone and tablet.

So, the limitations are:

- Can only print to Google cloud ready printers. Or classic printers that are connected to a PC.

YOU CANNOT DIRECTLY CONNECT A USB PRINTER TO A CHROMEBOOK, which renders my older Wi-Fi/Bluetooth printer, that is not cloud compatible, useless with my Chromebook. Fortunately, I can print to my husbands B&W laser printer, but not my awesome color photo printer.

- If you are planning on using this to replace a windows laptop or tower, you may need an external monitor, keyboard and mouse.

I have a Logitech wireless keyboard and mouse that uses the same USB dongle (Logitech's Unifying hardware that can connect up to 6 peripherals to one USB dongle.). This is great to save one of the two USB ports. I would have a printer in the other port... if it worked, but instead it has my phone charger in it. Have also ordered a 20" Samsung HDMI monitor. This Chromebook does have an HDMI port.

- New keyboard shortcuts to learn, and some standard keys not there.

E.g. delete - you have to press Alt+Backspace. This is pretty easy to get used to, but not a problem if you have an external keyboard, where all of the regular keys work just the way they should.

The number pad on the external wireless keyboard does not work with the built in calculator app on the Chromebook. The number pad works in general text situations only. That's too bad.

- Video camera is not awesome.

But it works and is acceptable. However - Google Chromebook DOES NOT SUPPORT SKYPE. That's right, you cannot use Skype on this baby. Instead, you are encouraged to use Google Hangouts. I would love to, but none of my chat friends are on there - ha.

Those limitations might be deal breakers for some, but I am still happy with my Samsung Chromebook. If I could print to a classic printer without using another PC, I would have given 5 stars. For the money, ease of use and portability, I don't regret being an owner.

I bought one of these roughly 6 months ago. Still have it, still works, still like it. Let's be real. You are getting this to surf the web, do your online shopping (hey, nobody makes viruses for these yet, right?! ... right?), eat your lunch on top of-- and it rocks at all of these things. I just bought my first, "I need to run REAL programs" work laptop-- while surfing Amazon from my Chromebook. I throw this thing in the kitchen to read recipes off of while I cook, and it blasts my Pandora at the same time. I don't sweat taking this to campus (I'm a Grad Student). If someone takes it-- well, I'm not out much money, and all my files are safely stowed away in this proverbial Cloud. Whatever that means, it works great.

The only real limitations with it arise when you actually try to use it as a "real" computer. No, when your graduate advisor sends you comments on your manuscript, you probably can't read them. Because she likely made her comments in Word 2010, and for whatever reason, Editor's Notes don't show up in Google Docs. And if you try to do a presentation, borrow a laptop or buy an adapter, because this one probably doesn't plug into the projector. And of course, while doing "Office-y" things, you're going to be working under all the constraints of Google Drive/Docs/Spreadsheet/Presentation/etc. Which are all pleasantly functional apps, but they do have their limitations, and they DON'T work as well as you'd hope when you're sharing documents with people who are opening them in equivalent Office programs.

As far as the trivial things that people care about in Web machines-- yeah, Google Chat is sort of not as cool as Skype. Or at least, the people who you have to CONVINCE to use Google Chat, because you can no longer Skype with them, will say so. (I like Google Chat, so whatever.) And the Webcam is pretty bare bones. Somewhere between "Not bad, just looks like you smeared finger grease across the lens," and "might have been captured with high-res potato." Also, I found in Chat that I had to turn my own volume WAY down (so I could barely hear the person I was chatting with), or else they got really bad echoing on THEIR machine. Speakers too close to microphone, I guess?

All in all, it's surprisingly clumsy-person-bulletproof, it does what you want it to do, it's less obnoxious (and probably more functional) than a comparatively-priced Tablet. No, it's not flawless-- but it's cheap enough it doesn't have to be.

o  Portability / weight

As everyone says, you open it up, and it automatically starts right up in no time at all. No bloated and expensive operating system to load here. The screen size suits me fine, and the sound is okay. There's only 16G of storage, but with with an SD card slot and two USB connections, you really have as much storage as you need. Need more storage? Just buy another SD card.

It's Google-centric of course, so you're automatically signed into all your Google accounts - gmail, youtube, drive and so on. Obviously, nothing is truly secure and private in the cloud, but I find using Drive for writing documents to be extremely convenient. No need to worry about losing anything, it's always up there in the cloud. I can get to my documents from my phone, my Nexus, or any connected computer, anywhere I go. You can also work on your documents if you happen to be offline, and it will auto-save locally and update to the cloud as soon as you're connected again. Again, really convenient.

Like most people, I often use my computer to surf the net. I've been using Chrome for a long time, and it works well on the Chromebook, naturally. It's also easy to view photos with the Chromebook, whether your pictures are on an SD card, or on the Chromebook drive.

As quickly as the Chromebook starts, it's just as quick shutting down. No need to twiddle your thumbs waiting for the OS to do its housekeeping. So far, the battery seems to be more than adequate. No problem there.

So, let me begin by saying that I am a software engineer and there is no way that this would be able to keep up with all of my computing needs. That being said, the avg person should find that it performs everything they need outside of a few minor caveats; so here they are:

Chrome OS is NOT for you if...

1) You MUST use iTunes. If you have an iDevice and plan on using this to sync music, contacts, etc. It's simply not going to work. However if you only plan on listening to music and your library is on another machine you can use Google's Music uploader to add your songs to the Google Music web interface.
2) You want to use this as your only computer with a printer that doesn't have Google Cloud Print support. If you have a PC or Mac on your network configuring Google Cloud Print is simple even with the oldest of computers.
3) You must use Micro$oft Office and are not okay with either Google Docs or the new Office 365 web apps.

Chrome OS IS for you if....

1) You realize that there are modern web only alternatives for almost anything you would do on a PC.
2) You want to use this as a secondary device that is more productive than a tablet.
3) You want computer maintenance to be a thing of the past and want a device that "just works".

Now I have read some of the negative reviews and seeing M$'s new Scroogled campaign let me clear up a few things:

1) Netflix does work to a satisfactory level with minor performance issues. It helps to have all other tabs closed.
2) This is a very thin and light plastic device with a VERY small power adapter. So if you abuse your electronics you might consider the HP Chromebook 11 (which has been pulled for now but I'm sure will reappear when they solve the heat issues with the power adapter)
3) There are no added privacy issues over simply using the Chrome browser or Android. Other than logging on with a Google account there is nothing that says that you actually have to use their services. You can still use your favorite mail, calendar and even search engine.
4) I have never had a crash (that I have noticed, it takes about 20 sec to restart and opens to the same tabs).

In the interest of full disclosure I will say that there is the occasional task that I want to perform that cannot be done in Chrome OS, however there are multiple options to remote into my desktop in order to accomplish what I want to do. Chrome has a new easy to use remote access application that is very simple with the only downside being that it doesn't resize the display of the target device to match like RDP. Speaking of which, there is a native RDP app that works quite well, but usually requires being on the same network. Same goes for VNC. The last free alternative that I have used and it works quite well is LogMeIn.

My tour was from North Carolina to California. Roughly in the middle of the tour, in Norton, Kansas, I dropped my Chromebook. I was in line at a McDs, getting a snack. As I picked it up, some one said "Did it break?" and I replied, "I don't know." After I got my snack and sat down. I opened it and saw no damage, so I turned it on and used it to check my email.

After I got to my motel that night. I noticed that many of the clips that hold the the plastic shells around both the display and the main part of the computer were opened. I carefully worked around both shells, pressing them back together and all of the  clips that were open clicked back into place. The only damage I could fine was a little marring, about 1/4" wide, on the front left corner. I don't think any of the many laptop computers I have owned, including several Toughbooks, would have survived that fall with so little damage.

Since I use it for photo editing, I wish it had more accurate color rendering on its display. Since I camp sometimes on tour and may be away from power outlets for several days, I also wish it had a swap-able battery so I could carry a spare. Its battery is replaceable, but that requires removing the bottom shell and unscrewing six screws which I wouldn't want to do on tour. Battery life is good - around six hours - and I carry an Anker external battery brick which can power the Chrome book for another four or five hours. That is good enough for me to create several days of web pages off line when I am camping.

I don't know if you're like me, but I have three desires. One, the protection of my data. Two, portability. Three, a smaller laptop type device with all the capabilities of a typical laptop.

My previous computer crashed due to a defective hard drive, and I found myself taking the longest time before buying the Chromebook. I also wanted something better than a typical tablet. Make no mistake this is a tablet on steroids. It is not a pc, but it is close offering most of benefits of a pc, and in some respects offers considerable advatages.

I bought it at a well known national retailer for about the same price as Amazon. What made me decide to buy this computer was the excellent advice given by someone from google who worked at the store.

May I say that in terms of sophistication and ease of use it far exceeds a tablet device. I own a Nook, but I would not use it for buying an airline ticket, for example.

The following made me decide to buy:

100 gb of free storage for two years, offering considerable saving on online storage.
Able after easy setup to walk out of the store with it working.
The possibility of google cloud printing.
The fact that you press a button and it's on, like a calculator.
It updates automatically.
It has in built antivirus protection, so you do not have to purchase software.
You have the full benefit of the google technology, including drive.
You have a wide range of apps available, particularly for document production, and its compatible with MS Office, and ODT.
It also has pdf apps that are excellent, and you can easily convert a document into a pdf for easy printing..

Other factors I liked after purchasing.

It's light, compact, and easy to carry.
It's very quick at connecting to new networks if you're roaming.
It has great battery life about 6.5 hours, and this can vary depending on the nature of your usage.
It even has an indicator which tells how much battery life is left.
Google Drive offers you the opportunity to sign in and access your documents from anywhere.
You can also create documents from anywhere, and even share documents online and allow other people to edit your document.

Comparison to full pc laptop. For an extra $50 you can buy a laptop.

On this computer you can do most but not all of what you can do on a regular computer. This is an absolutely excellent internet computing device. It's quick, and can process a lot of content, and you can have multiple windows open simultaneously without any noticeable slowdown. Unlike a regular PC it will never slow down.

Automatic updates mean you never have to shut down it down like a regular pc to make updates.

It does not have a cd player, so if cd burning is important, this is not for you. You can listen to your music collection on google cloud. I can easily listen to my amazon cloud music for example.

It works with apps not with software. There are plenty of applications you can get at the google store many for free.

I found that I cannot use Snagit on this computer to capture content. I use my pc for that.

I love streaming movies on this machine. The pictures are crisp and vibrant, the sound excellent.
I could watch a movie in bed without any of the awkward balancing you might have with a regular pc.

Around the same time I bought this I also got a regular Dell PC. By comparison this is way faster to get going on. The Windows 8 apps on my new PC I found very annoying. They do not seem to work very well, and it's like running an obstacle course to get to a regular desktop setting.

Although the google cloud printing was a major selling point, I went to another national retailer and bought an Epson 3520, which the salesperson assured me was cloud compatible. It's the most up to date. But when I attempted to integrate it with this machine it was not cloud compatible. So, if you do go for a cloud ready printer, research the makes and models before you go to the store, as salespeople do not always know.

I like to Skype, so that was one of the considerations of getting the Chromebook which does not have skype. It does have calling and video calling capabilities called google talk, which I assume are comparable to skype.

Experience

I find that I love the Chromebook, and I tend to use it more than my two regular laptops, which I would be reluctant to take anywhere when I have this more compact, lightweight portable alternative. This is the number one seller in it's category on Amazon, and Samsung makes an excellent machine.

As it's a Linux based operating system you will become acquainted with the Google Chrome browsing instead of window. The google drive you can access anywhere even from a different computer, and access your original bookmarks. I bookmark many sites, and I found the bookmarking somewhat preferable on the windows explorer browser.

One of the ideas I love is the online storage, which means I could be in a different country yet still able to access 100 gb of content online, which offers considerable advantages over a tablet.

I find this to be great hybrid between the tablet and laptop, and I highly recommend it.

I think you will love it, and I hope this was helpful.

My Chrombook stopped working after just two weeks.  I called Samsung support.  They asked me to try a reset, but the Chromebook was still dead. The response I got via email was that the warranty was voided because I used the wrong power supply.  Included in the email was a photo of a power supply I had never seen before.  It was not a brick-type supply at all, but instead one of those smaller power supplies used with the old style cell phones.  I called to dispute this.  The person I talked to was a Samsung employee.  She put me on hold while she communicated by dispute with Intellisol. She then emailed me screenshots from a video that Intellisol had made when the technician opened the carton I had shipped.  These two screen shots clearly showed the incorrect power supply.  The only problem is that I did not ship them this incorrect power supply.  I shipped the power supply I received with the system.  So, I don't know whose box they were opening when they took the video, and how that video got associated with my unit.  At that point, I had nothing to say, since it was my word against Intellisol's video screen shots.  I asked how much it would cost to repair the unit, and was told $200.  I did not want to invest any more money in this Chromebook, so I asked them to sent it back to me un-repaired.  When I received it, it was operational! You have to know that you get what you pay for. The Samsung Chromebook is excellent for it's price. And those cheesy videos they have that talk about how "chrome os gets better with automatic updates" are actually true. Having owned the Chromebook for almost a year now, nearly all my complaints have been patched over time. The main ones are full screen mode and HDMI playback.

You'll notice pretty quickly that the 11-inch screen has an aspect ratio that makes it more of a widescreen, which is great. However, when it's only 11 inches, having a taskbar and browser controls take up a good amount of room. Especially when you're in google docs, and there's another inch of viewing space taken off by those controls, it feels like you're looking at your content through a mail slot. Full screen mode was frustrating at first because every time your cursor got near the top of the screen, a pop-up showed up reminding you that you were in full screen mode. Okay. The new update actually makes you're content full-screen, and there are these thin, unobtrusive, minimalist-style lines at the top and bottom of the display that represent your current tab and window. Your current tab/window are signified a white line while your other open tabs are grayed out lines. It may seem like a small thing, but it's helpful when you're using it.

HDMI video playback actually works like it should have in the first place. Before, when you plugged in HDMI, your Chromebook display turned off and the monitor was the only display. Kind of useless. Watching movies on my TV through the Chromebook seemed cool in theory, but streaming was choppy and audio was delayed. Somewhere over the months that I've owned it, an update came through that changed it all. Now, the external display is defaulted to extend your Chromebook display, and a large variety of native resolutions are compatible. It even looked great on my 47 inch tv. And video playback is now flawless over HDMI.

If you can't decide whether or not the Chromebook is for you, it's not too hard. If you are looking for a laptop for video/photo editing, programming, gaming, or other graphics and cpu intensive hardware, or even something that requires actual software, the Chromebook isn't for you. Essentially it's a browser. The computer just gives you the hardware to access the browser. The keyboard and trackpad are pretty good. If you like your bluetooth/wired keyboard and mouse better, go ahead and use them because they'll work just fine.

If you're like me and really just use the Internet, the Chromebook is great. You have access to all Google products, Pandora, Spotify (the web player is getting better), and others. If Microsoft office is a must, check out the online SkyDrive by Microsoft, because they have online, dumbed-down free versions of Word, Excel, and Powerpoint on there that give you basic functions. SkyDrive works great on the Chromebook too. But Google Docs is getting better. It used to be pretty limited, but it's amazing how far it's come.

Just test yourself with your computer you already have. Every time you log on, how many times do you not click on the Internet browser? I found myself finding this true. Why buy a crazy expensive laptop when this will do you just fine? Find out for yourself.

I have owned this Samsung Chromebook for quite some time now. I won't repeat what everyone else had already said about it, only very quickly that I love it to the point that it is now my go to laptop even at home. But I do want to give you some ideas how to turn this into a legitimate productivity machine.

1. Office Documents:

If you do a lot of office documents, Google now has Quickoffice integrated into the Chrome browser. For a document without a lot of fancy formatting Quickoffice works great. This should address at least 90% of most people's need. It seems to me that Quickoffice is actually available offline. A slightly negative aspect of it is that Quickoffice seems sluggish from time to time. I don't whether this is due to the ARM processor.

If you want a more authentic MS Office experience you can always upload your document to Skydrive, which is very easy to do from a chromebook. You will then be able to edit Office documents using the Office Web App. I have done this many many times with no glitch what so ever. I have even edited complex Power Point presentations.

But my favorite is to convert most of my Word documents into Google Docs. Editing them is extremely smooth, and they can be made available for offline editing. Most of the time I just use Google Docs. Sometimes I convert them into Word documents, which is easy to do on a chromebook or a PC.

2. Google Drive and Dropbox  Integration

Nothing needs to be said here about Google Drive. Gdrive is fully integrated into the Chrome OS, and serves as a local drive. However, Dropbox is not. I'm still waiting for Google to come through, and rumor has it that it will eventually come.

But there are easy get-around fixes. The first one I would recommend is a free app called SourceKit. It is an editor that edits files directly in your Dropbox and save them there. The second one I use is ShiftEdit (I use the free version). This is an even more powerful editor. You can set up your Dropbox account as the workspace, and then you can edit your files directly in dropbox. The ShiftEdit editor is much more powerful than SourceKit, but also more "intimidating" perhaps to setup. Of course, one can always use the web Dropbox interface, and it is just that an extra step to upload back to dropbox after you are done.

3. LaTeX

I do a lot of LaTeX, so it is important that the Chromebook can handle it. In the Chrome OS it is possible, as there are several cloud-based LaTeX engines. LaTexlab is one of them I actually like that is very easy to use. However, I find that it is a cinch to install Crouton Linux on this chromebook and switch back and forth between Linux and Chrome OS without reboot. It is also easy to install the full version of LaTeX and TeXmaker, one of the best LaTeX editors. So now I have completely solved the LaTeX issue.

4. Editing/Making html webpage

ShiftEdit is a GREAT editor for making/editing webpages. It is almost as good as Adobe's Dreamweaver! I teach a class so I constantly need to update my webpage, and ShiftEdit is incredibly handy.

5. SSH and SFTP

I could not find a good app for it, so it was frustrating until I realized that SSH and SFTP are build into the Developer's Mode. For those of you who are willing to enter the Developer's Mode, go to Google and search for it. There are a ton of step-by-step guide for it. Once you have enable Developer's Mode, press ALT+CRL+T. A shell like window will appear. Type "shell" to enter a shell. Then just type sftp hostname to run it. It is command line based so you may have to learn if you haven't used it before. But it is very simple.

I would love to know if there is a simpler way. (I could not get sftp to work in my Crouton Linux environment, perhaps because of the ARM processor).

6. Free Phone Calls/Text Messages

The Google Hangout works very nicely on this Chromebook. With it you can make/receive free calls to numbers in the US and Canada as long as you have a Google Voice number (free from Google). You can do this free even if you are outside the US. By the way, this is one area where the Chromebook definitely shines over a tablet. I have tried several VOIP apps on my iPad and my Android tablet. They quality has never been comparable.

7. Linux

This is one of favorite part. It is very easy to install Crouton Linux (again a ton of step by step guide), Once you install it it is trivial to switch between the two operating systems (CTL+ALT+SHFT+arrow to go from one to another). I installed the full version of LaTeX (TeX Live) and the editor TeXmaker. However, I have trouble getting LibreOffice, Skype, SSH and other programs to work, even though I noticed that others managed to get them to work on this machine. If any of you can help me out here I would really appreciate it.

8. Offline capabilities

A lot have been written about the offline capabilities (or the lack of them) of the Chromebook. Actually there are plenty of offline capabilities. In particular, you can almost always do enough offline and add just a little bit finishing touch to complete a task when you are back online again. For example, there is a nice offline plain text editor "Text". Google Docs are available for offline use, and I seem to be able to use QuickOffice with no problem. Gmail offline works great and is a must for every gmail user. Of course, you can always go the the Linux side and do a bunch of stuff. In a nutshell, I have never had any problem getting most of my tasks completed when I have no internet connection.

9. Expanding Storage

The SD card slot is awkward because about 40% of the card will stick out. If you wan to permanently stick a SD card in the Chromebook as an expanded memory this can easily damage the card. There is a little trick solution to this nuisance. I bought a 32GB micro-SD card and on eBay a SD/USB adapter for the micro-SD card (less than $2). I then cut off the USB portion of it. The new contraption now is flush without anything sticking out, and it works. I did not discover this myself --- it was discussed on the web perhaps first among the Macbook Air community.

Incidentally, I rarely put photos on it so to be 16GB is actually enough, even with Linux installed. If you plan to add music, I highly recommend Google Music.

10. Concluding Remarks

A lot of things have been written about chromebooks, and a common theme is that it is great for unsophisticated users but not so useful for advanced users. This is totally untrue.  I consider myself to be an advanced user, and I have been able to do just about anything I want to do on this chromebook.

But if I have to buy a chromebook again, I may opt for one of those Intel Haswell chip based models. This particular chromebook can be sluggish sometimes. I have experienced it running Quickoffice, for example. I also have trouble install some apps which can potentially be very useful (e.g. Skype, SSH and LibreOffice on Linux). This is why I only give it 4 stars. It is possible that I am the only one experiencing these difficulties, and if so I would love to know.

I got two of these through DonorsChoose for my 8th grade special education classroom. As others have stated - these are NOT laptops. Instead, they are essentially tablets with keyboards. These are an excellent option for classrooms, or as a backup when traveling and all you want to to do browse the web, check emails, go on Facebook, and the like. I chose these over tablets because of the keyboards and the USB ports.

They are lightweight and I find the batteries hold a decent charge. My students really like them. I am able to just give a student one (so portable!) whenever they finish their work before others. They go online to use educational programs, both free and purchased (IXL, SpellingCity, AdaptedMind, Free Rice, etc). They can take their Accelerated Reader tests. All of these programs run perfectly on these machines - they never freeze (as happens on laptops and computers), and respond quickly to commands.

My only issue, and it is not a deal breaker, is that I wish they would have more educational apps available. I do use some that are offered. But, there is a limited number offered, especially for the middle school level. I am assuming as their popularity grows, this will be addressed.

Overall, these are excellent machines. I am thinking of getting one for my son who just likes to go on the web.

I have had the chromebook for approximately 9 months.  I bought it for 2 purposes.  The first is that I used to travel often, and it was absolutely the perfect size for travel.  I could take it on an airplane easily, and I loved the offline features.  The second purpose was for graduate school.  I didn't want to shell out the money for a full laptop to take back to school, but I wanted one that would do what I needed it to.  This is perfect for school.  I can take notes, I can use the internet, and google drive is possibly the best thing to ever happen to me (that may be a slight exaggeration, but I'm going for emphasis here.)  While I had google drive before, I find myself using it for everything now.  I can download docs in microsoft format on a school computer when I need to print something, I send in a different format, and I can pull it up on my ipad or phone.  (Yes, I do realize that this portion of the review is focused more on google drive than the chromebook itself, but you really don't realize how much you'll use google docs until you purchase a chromebook).

My two complaints about the chromebook are
1)  the battery life does begin to diminish fairly quickly.  When I first bought it, I got 6 hours easily from one charge.  I've still had it less than a year, and I'm down to 4ish hours of battery.  Now, that's still A LOT.  So I'm not entirely complaining about it.  But I am worried that if this is a pattern, the battery life will be pretty small in the future.  Since I am using this for class, 4+ hours of battery life is a must.
2)  I am finding that my chromebook has a much more difficult time finding wifi networks that it already knows.  This sounds weird...but it really will take a long time to connect to the wifi.  It will find other networks, but when I open my laptop up in the morning, sometimes it takes 5-10 minutes to find the home network.  When I go to the local coffee shop that I frequent, it sometimes won't find the network at all.  This is HUGELY frustrating to me.  I'm not a techie, so I don't know if there's something I'm doing wrong, but having chatted with another chromebook owner, I found that they've had this happen to them as well.  So clearly there is a small issue there.

Overall, I like my chromebook.  I would buy it again, and I would recommend it to others.  Sure, it has it's problems that others have mentioned, such as the netflix issue and inability to add applications, but it's a netbook!  I'm not expecting the capabilities of a full laptop.  If that's what you want, shell out the money for one.  Otherwise, buy one of these and you will be fairly happy with the simplicity and effectiveness of it.

My name is Chris and I am currently a freshman in college. As a college student, I find the Samsung Chromebook to be extremely convenient. At $250, this laptop is a steal.

First off, let me say that this is not your normal laptop. You cannot get Microsoft Office on this device as well as you cannot download really any programs on it. The Chromebook operates on the Cloud and strictly on Google's programs; whether it be G-mail, Google Drive, Google Calendar, Google Keep, etc. So if you are not already a "Google-ite", once you purchase this laptop you will become one.

The Chromebook laptop has very minimal internal storage space. So your files and pictures and such do not get stored physically on the computer. Your files and pictures and whatever else you might be saving get put on the Cloud on Google Drive. Upon the purchase of your Chromebook, you receive a free 100 GB of Google Drive storage for 2 years. So you don't really need to worry about running out of room in the cloud. This laptop operates solely on Wi-Fi connection. Everything that you do on this laptop is in a sense, on the Google Chrome browser. So you will need internet for almost all functions on this laptop. However, there is an offline mode if you do not have Wi-Fi connection where you can still type up documents and such.

If you're trying to decide what computer to get for college and you're going through a rough time deciding if you want a desktop with a laptop, if you want only a laptop, or if you want to go the tablet route, I was in the exact same boat when I was deciding what I wanted. After having been in college now for 2 and a half months now, I am very happy with my decision with the Chromebook. I myself have an iMac desktop computer in my dorm room as my main computer and I take my Chromebook to class. I use it every day and it is works perfectly for in class usage. I will go to class or go to the library and type up whatever I need to on Google Docs or Google Sheets, and if I need to print it out or if I want to edit the format of the document a little bit more, I will download the Google Drive document onto my desktop and then edit them in Microsoft Office. (Sort of a system that I have developed)

The one thing about this computer that I have to point out is the battery life. I have found that the standby battery life on the Chromebook is not as good as you think it would be.

If you are in search of a portable computer for college, I would definitely recommend this computer to you. It is very convenient, extremely light, and a cute and small size. However, personally I would NOT get this Chromebook if you plan on making this your main computer. The Chromebook is a cheap alternative to a laptop that is best for carrying around in your backpack as an addition to your main computer. I personally find myself using my Chromebook more than I do my desktop computer.

However making this laptop your main computer IS doable, it is not IDEAL but it can be done. Really, in this day in age, Microsoft Office is not entirely necessary. Google Docs, Sheets, and Slides are pretty good alternatives to Microsoft Office. BUT, the Google word processors do not have nearly as many functions as Microsoft Office has, so be forewarned. The Google applications have all of the basic functions... nothing more.

IN MY OPINION:
I have looked at other people who use tablets as their in-class computers and I have talked with them to see how they like their decision to go with the tablet route, and most of them say that they regret the decision to go tablet instead of laptop. They claim that it is difficult to keep up with the professor trying to continually type on the touchscreen. (Although there are now keyboards for your tablets). So, as a current college student, I recommend weigh your options before going the tablet route for your in class computer. And I would DEFINITELY consider the Samsung Chromebook.

OK - here's my take on this product.  Pros:  Small, light, comes on quickly, is basically Linux with a Chrome overlay (so it's pretty much virus free), great battery life.  Now cons:  Keyboard lacks some pretty vital keys (delete for one), too many keyboard shortcuts (you can't remember them all), touchpad is 'quirky' (and I'm being kind here - it sucks!), screen is dim (even at max brightness), needs more memory and a bigger hard drive (the cloud isn't my favorite for storing personal info).  Overall, if you've never used a computer, this is a nice intro devise.  For experienced users, it's not worth the time or trouble to get (basically) a tablet with a keyboard for around $250. I am a student at a big university. One day I was walking through a local store and this caught my eye. I played with it for a bit, and decided to check Amazon for the best price. I purchased one to have something smaller, lighter, and cheaper than my Apple computer to take to class. I commute to school, so when I am there I primarily type papers/take notes, watch youtube videos, and use social media. This Chromebook has been absolutely perfect for my needs. I am using it right now to type this review as it is my lighter and smaller to use while sitting on the couch. Google Drive is an excellent tool to use across all operating systems, and it is great that they give you 100GB free for 2 years. That is a deal for a computer that is only costing you $250. I am very happy with my purchase, however, there a few things I would like to bring up.

For a cheap computer, the build quality is very good. However, after having it for about 6 months now, things have started to show some wear. Through life in my backpack, the lid has gotten very scratched. However, for $20 on Amazon, I found a skin for the top lid that looks great and covers the wear, so thats no longer an issue. The only thing that shows its wear is the hinge. The hinge makes some noise and has a clunky feel to it when you open the computer, but the screen does not wiggle around, nor does it feel like the hinge is going to come apart. Just something I have noticed.

All in all, this a great product for someone looking for a small system to browse the web and watch some videos with it. For the price if it gets broken, it isn't the biggest deal in the world. I think this is perfect for a student to use in conjunction with another computer.

For me the cons are it can't run Java and no backlit keyboard. Lately I've had a problem with connecting to the internet at my school. When I boot up the laptop it'll prompt you to log in to your Google account, just enter your password and go. Well what has been happening instead of saying "Enter password" "Sign in" will show up like it's the first time with the laptop. So I click "Sign in" and it has to connect to the internet to do so.
