I've had my Chromebook since last spring. I read many reviews before I made my purchase, so I already knew what I was getting. I have a Windows 7 desktop and 2 Sony laptops, so I really didn't need my Chromebook for the functions for which I use my regular computers (mostly image and video editing). I needed a fast and simple path online and something more portable than my laptops, but still with a full-size keyboard. My Chromebook was the perfect solution. It starts almost instantly, and I'm online before my other computers are finished booting. It's very light and perfect for travel, and I have been getting more than 6 hours of use from the battery-- sometimes even 7 hours. I'm very happy with the suite of Google applications included. I had never used GoogleDocs before, but I found it easy to use, and for me, preferable to Word. I like that I can export from the Google applications to Microsoft applications if I need to, but mostly I simply keep my documents online in my GoogleDrive-- which I also love. With the Android GoogleDrive app on my phone, I have access to my files all of the time. The Chromebook is fast enough when I am surfing online, and I have never had any problems-- even with watching HD movies on Netflix. It is very convenient that the Chromebook has 2 USB ports (1 USB 3.0), an SD card slot, and an HDMI port. My USB ports instantly recognized my terabyte portable drive and every other USB storage device that I connected (also my wireless mouse, which I prefer over the trackpad). The HDMI port means that I don't need any other device to stream movies to my high definition television. I simply plug in my Chromebook into a TV HDMI port, and I'm ready to go. The Chrome operating system has been much improved (as promised) since I bought my Chromebook. Originally, the picture viewer would frequently hang up when viewing a large number of files, and the movie player couldn't play .AVI movies from my external drive without sputtering and skipping frames. After several automatic updates, both issues have been completely resolved. (The music player does not play .wma files, so you will have to convert them to .mp3.) I'm very happy with my Chromebook. It has delivered everything that it promised.

If you want a cheap computer that you only want to use for an hour or two at a time, chromebook may be fine, but for surfing for hours, don't waste your money.  Get something better made.

I've had my Chromebook for about 5 months now.  I originally bought it to take on an extended summer vacation.  I needed a way to pay bills and keep up with email and family while on a 6 week trip.  I didn't want an expensive full blown computer with a power hungry hard drive and an OS that needed virus protection and constant updates.  I was a bit concerned with some of the reports of problems on this site, but decided that for $250, I'd take my chances.

  The little Samsung performed perfectly. It survived a month and a half of camping quite well.  Whenever I came across a WiFi connection, it booted up within a few seconds and I was in business. Since I rarely used it for more than an hour at a time, I only needed to charge it about once a week.  It really runs 6 - 6.5 hrs. on a charge.  I even learned to video chat with friends and make phone calls through Google's free service (can't beat the price!).  While this will never replace my 'real' computer, it has everything and can do everything that a traveling computer should do.  It also doesn't have many things that are not needed.  Heavy drive to hold big OS, heavy battery to power heavy drive, fans to cool all that heavy equipment...  It's actually more like a smartphone with an great screen and excellent keyboard.  There are Google apps to perform most common computer functions in the cloud.  I plugged in a 32G SD card for extra local storage, but I haven't needed it.

  I'm happy to report that I have not had any of the freezing or rebooting issues that some have complained about.  Since returning from my trip I've been using the 'book for Internet access at home, instead of firing up the desktop.  I also hook it up (via the HDMI port) to my TV to watch movies and TV shows on Netflix, Hulu, and Viewster.  Works great, especially for Hulu, which has some shows that are only available to computer browsers (i.e. not to TVs or mobile devices).

  Overall, the little Samsung exceeded my expectations.  I never expected it to edit video or do high end gaming, but as it turns out, it does quite a bit more than I thought it could.

  BTW, my coworker checked my 'book out right after I bought it.  He has since bought two of them and is very happy with them.

I own a dell studio 15 and I was getting tired of lugging it around and having to fight for tables with outlets when studying at a coffee shop, or only getting an hour's work done before it died. I needed something smaller, lighter, and with a better battery life. While I would love a macbook air, I'm not in a position to spend $1200 for a device at this time. That's when I started looking at Chromebooks. The only hangup I had was that I had to be online to get any use out of it, and then I realized that I am always online. It takes a little bit to get it set up the way I wanted it but after that it does everything I need it to, I can even access my iCloud account online and update my to do list and calendar.  Well, almost. There are certain test that I have to take for school that I need a regular PC for, and then there is my iTunes account. For those I use my laptop at home. Even then I can remotely access my computer from anywhere. I love writing on it, the keyboard is very good. I used it on a trip to DC, and was able to get work done on the train gong up and back. The fact that I usually only charge it at night like a cell phone is a plus.

  I will warn anyone who is considering buying one that this is not for those who need to replace their powerful PC, the lack of significant hardrive space and Chrome's limited OS will frustrate someone coming from a Macbook pro or other $1000 computer. This is for those who are already comfortable working in the cloud, or need a small, light, second computer with a great battery. If that's you then I highly recommend it.

  As far as word processing goes, I have a skydrive account. I can access all of my documents, open them with the online version of Microsoft office. I'm a creature of habit and I don't like Google docs for daily use. I'm not really big photo social media guy, I only use Linked in and Facebook so I cannot speak to that for anyone. If I listen to music I use Google play and synced all of my iTunes music to it so I have access to everything I own. I rarely use the speakers, I prefer headphones as I am often out in public. I don't watch movies on the Chromebook, I only watch lectures for school and they are usually of poor video quality to begin with. If I'm gonna watch a movie I'll watch it on my HD tv at home, never really understood the need to watch movies on tiny screens. (I know I'm a boring old man).

  So if you're looking for something that turns heads, and does everything your Mac (or your friends Mac) does don't buy a Chromebook. But if you need an inexpensive, reliable device for working in the cloud then this is for you.

I've been using my Chromebook for about a year now, using it almost daily at home and traveling. It's small, light, has good battery life (I get about 8 hours with intermittent use), and pretty much hassle-free. OS updates are automatic, files save automatically, there are apps available to do almost anything you want, and screen is good from text and video. Netflix is now supported!

Downsides. Despite the protests of chromeheads, it really is just a browser--no internet and it's pretty much just a paperweight as most apps are served out of the cloud. The tight control over the OS and apps has locked out open source software such as Open Office, LibreOffice, Banshee, etc., and the Chrome alternatives just aren't as good. Games available are lame.

A downside of hassle-free is that it's difficult or impossible to save a Google Sheet or Doc in another format if you want to move files between apps or share with a non-Chromebook. Formatting and functions available in the Google Office apps are basic, but a user used to MS Office or any of the open source alternatives will be disappointed.  The last automatic OS update has screwed up my ability to access my daily e-newspaper, and the lack of a roll-back has me in deep yogurt until the bug is discovered, diagnosed, and fixed (my non-Chrome devices still work).

The keyboard has a nice feel, but its non-standard (PC) layout can be frustrating, e.g. the lack of a delete key (it's alt-backspace), no F2 edit, etc.

In short, I like it to check my email and browse internet, especially while traveling, but Chromebook is handicapped by the lack of 'big boy' apps and games.

I bought this in a hurry when my old Dell laptop died right before school started and this was all I could afford. It's worth what I paid, which is to say it's not worth a lot, but it works. Altogether, it's fine, but I wouldn't buy it again if I had the money to buy a non-Chromebook. I knew I'd suffer a little for the Chrome OS, but I didn't realize just how much because I'm not tech-savvy. I find it's pretty limited in what it can do (especially regarding schoolwork) but it covers the essentials acceptably, which is really all I should expect from a $220 machine.

Pros:

-The lack of startup time is fantastic! Being able to open it up and have it going in 10 seconds is really, really great. I was used to taking 5+ minutes just to get on my e-mail with my old dying Dell laptop.
-Lightweight and sleek; easy to transport; great for bringing to class
-good battery life
-questionably powerful enough for my needs, but not for my wants (see below)
-durable (?)

Cons:

-After almost 6 months of use, the performance seems to be getting progressively worse. When I first got it, things ran amazingly smoothly. I could have 8 tabs open (facebook, Youtube in the background, a document, buzzfeed articles queued up) and nothing would stutter and it all loaded quickly. Not anymore. Even simple pages can take forever to load. Sometimes, it works perfectly fine and other times, it's hardly functional. Closing superfluous tabs doesn't help-- it can run just as slow on a single pdf as it does with 7 buzzfeed articles open. I have these problems both running it on my home internet and school internet. Ultimately, the internet always works but it's just ridiculously slow sometimes. I would summarize the performance as being wildly inconsistent.

-It seems to run worse when it's not plugged in.

-Google Docs is awful on in its own right and the machine can barely run it. It stutters incessantly (possibly due to the constant auto-saving?) and it's basically impossible to make a well-organized, attractive document in Docs on a Chromebook. Skydrive (online MS Office) is not much better considering the Chrome OS limitations and the auto-saving. In either of these word processors, the lag is unbearable. If I need to type more than one page, it's literally less of a hassle for me to travel to school/stay later to do assignments than it is to produce them on the Chromebook. I have a >50-page document due at the end of every semester and I would rather eat my own tongue than attempt to even OPEN it on my Chromebook, let alone type it up.

-Don't even get me started on opening/trying to edit MS Word docs on a Chromebook. It opens in a program called QuickOffice which is awful. Documents are ugly and the formatting is ruined. Normally crashes if I try to edit them. One time, it crashed every time I hit the left shift key. Other times (95% of the time), it just crashes out of nowhere.

-You cannot use any Apple or Microsoft software. Considering that the world runs on these companies, this is a MAJOR drawback of the Chromebook. I had no idea it'd be this inconvenient. I can't use my school-specific software, watch some required videos, run some required software,or create and/or reasonably edit MS Office things.

-On that note, you need an app for EVERYTHING. If it's not a website, you probably need an app.

-The plastic shell feels kind of flimsy, especially around the trackpad. Sitting it on top of soft things (ex your knee, laptop sleeve) seems to screw up clicking-- almost like you could click by pressing on the underside of the shell under the trackpad. If you press on the shell next to the trackpad, you can see the whole keyboard rock. Still, like I said above, it does seem durable. Honestly, I've been known to slam the heel of my hand down on the trackpad/hand rest part when I get upset and it hasn't shown any signs of wear and tear. After almost 6 months, the plastic casing on the back of the keyboard part, like where all the ports are, is coming off. It clicks back on but I'm afraid of that the consequence will be if I can't put it back on someday. I've never dropped this thing or banged it off something, so I don't know why it's coming off.

-It sometimes ignores my clicks? I feel like sometimes (by that I mean daily, just not every time) I have to click on things multiple times in order for the Chromebook to register it. No signs of loading, etc-- just it acting as if I never clicked at all.

So, in summary, I wouldn't buy this Chromebook again if I had other options, but it'll do until I can afford to replace it with a Windows machine. It just doesn't cut it for my schoolwork and it isn't even good for entertainment. It works but not really that well. It does what I absolutely, bottom-line NEED it to do, but it doesn't do it how I want or expect it to. I would say it's like a splint when what I really need is a cast. In a pinch, it's much better than nothing but it's just not sufficient in the long run.

The screen is small and you cannot download Java.  I would like to use this computer for online banking but without Java it is pretty much useless.  If you just want to use it for e-mail and browsing it is fast.

Not a laptop replacement...but then again, I don't think any real Chromebook user would ever assert something so bold. However, I can definitely say that I now spend ~80% of my computing time on my Chromebook. It's fast, lightweight, and long-lasting (battery wise). Considering that most of us now spend most of our time using the computer to use the internet, why wouldn't I use my Chromebook? I still chuckle at people who cry out "BUT IT CAN'T DO ANYTHING WITHOUT THE INTERNETS!" Let's be honest: how often do you use your computer for non-internet related things? That's right. I thought so. Take that, average computer user.

So yes, I really do love my Chromebook. I don't regret my purchase at all. $250 was a steal for this product, as far as I'm concerned (and I'm a broke college student). It was especially vital in allowing me to successfully write my ~100pg undergraduate thesis, as the portability allowed me to work everywhere (my room, Starbucks, friends' rooms, library, professor's office, etc.).

Cons: Yes, there are a few downsides. (1) Build quality is shoddy. Which I guess is a given, given the price. The paint is starting to come off, especially near where I rest my wrists. I also make sure to pick it up carefully, as the base feels a little 'loose' and I worry that it could split in half. I recommend closing and picking it up when you have to do so.
(2) Ram. Yup, I'm still spoiled by laptop/desktop usage. The Chromebook definitely can't handle 50 open tabs without freezing/crashing. There is occasional lag depending on the intensity of whatever you're trying to run.

Overall: A+ would recommend. Cheap laptop supplement. Google is great about pushing out frequent Chrome OS updates, and it's safe to say that my device runs even better than it did when I first got it. I'll also add that I love not having to worry about it getting stolen- All my stuff is in the cloud and can be instantly restored to a new device!

Instead of writing a long narrative, I'll just provide the list of pros and cons that I wish I would have seen prior to purchasing this computer.  I got it about 10 months ago (just before last Christmas; it was one of the first produced) and have been using it every day since.

Pros:
* Price point.  Can't beat that.
* Weight.  It honestly feels like I'm not carrying anything - I once picked up the neoprene case and almost didn't realize it was empty.
* Battery life.  I kid you not, I have gotten 7 hours out of the battery.  That's 7 hours of use, not 7 hours with the monitor off in sleep mode.
* Boot speed.  Almost a year in, boot speed is the same as it always was, and it gets me to the login screen in 3 seconds.  Full login in under 10 seconds.
* Crash recovery.  When the computer or a window crashes, Chrome reopens everything the way it was.

Cons:
* The body is made of plastic. This wouldn't be a big deal, but if you pick it up by the palm rest (like most people do) it causes the touchpad to click.  Likewise, if you rest too much weight on your palms, it causes the mouse to click spontaneously.
* As an extension of that, the SD card slot has a door on it.  The plastic on it is total crap.  I can't pinpoint any abuse that would cause this, but mine broke off.
* Video capabilities.  The computer can't handle youtube videos in high resolution, much less if you load an AVI onto the machine.
* Remember, no executable files.  Everyone should know this already, but you can't install programs on this machine.  Just Chrome extensions.
* Processor power.  As best I can tell, for tabs containing mild graphics, the machine maxes out around 5-8 tabs.  I think it may have a memory leak as well, as windows left open for over 24 hours have a habit of crashing.

Basically, this is a great computer at an unbeatable price, but you need to go into it being aware of its limitations or you will be disappointed.

A Chromebook runs the Chrome web browser sitting on top of a Linux core.  If the bulk of your computing takes place in a web browser, you will find the Chromebooks meet your needs.  If you need to run specific Windows-based software, this is probably not the computer for you.

That said, I find my Samsung runs Chrome fairly fast, about the same as a decent Window-based laptop with a fast Internet connection.  There are a growing number of "offline apps" now, so you can do many functions if no Internet is available:  word processing, spreadsheets, presentations, file operations including videos and music, e-books, e-mail editing, games, etc.

I like the full-size keyboard and the track-pad.  The screen is 11 inches on the diagonal, and the speakers are loud (though a bit tinny).  The display is crisp and clear; the surface is a dull matte finish which I strongly prefer over the glossy, glaring surface that most screens seem to have these days.  Wireless connection was extremely simple to set up, and connection strength seems very good.  There are ports for an SD card, USB 2 and USB 3, and HDMI.

The weight is only a little over 1 kilogram, and I find that the battery life is pretty decent - about 6 hours of web-browsing.  I read some comments from folks who say the shell is `creaky', but I find the construction and materials to be reasonably solid - about the same as any other sub-$500 laptop.

I think it is the ideal device for someone who would be okay with a tablet, but wants a full-size real keyboard rather than touch screen.

I'm a full time student and was sick of my computer kicking its fan on because it randomly decided to start downloading a Windows Service Pack in the middle of the day while I was trying to take notes.  It was a full-sized, full-powered Sony Vaio and it was bulky, heavy, and loud.  When I heard about the Chromebook, it seemed like a great idea, but I was apprehensive about learning the new OS and not being able to download Windows programs.  I would like to outline some of my initial concerns and put them to rest for anyone who is thinking about getting a Chromebook:

1. "I will miss all my Windows programs!"  I doubt it.  If you're looking for a computer to take with you to school, then everything you're going to do can be done online.  You don't need Office or anything like that when you utilize GoogleDocs, which YOU WILL LOVE.  Now that all my documents are in the cloud, it makes updating them, sharing them, printing them, all so much easier.  If you're worried you'll miss your games, GoogleApps has thousands of them that seem awesome.  Plus, if you're looking for a timewaster between classes (or during?) you can still access Facebook and Pinterest!

2. "I'll have to relearn the Operating System." True, but you'll learn it immediately after you try something the first time. It's SO fast and so efficient and it's only the things you need.  It's Google, so it's intuitive.  Now, when I go back to use my desktop or someone else's laptop, I really see how streamlined the Chromebooks are.

3. "Isn't 11.6" going to be to small?" Not at all.  I've seen some netbooks that are tiny and I hoped beyond hope that the Chromebook would be big enough and it absolutely is.  I'm super short, so in lecture halls, I always had to look over my old 15" laptop to see my professors.  I can see over this comfortably and the screen is PLENTY big to see everything (and the screen is beautiful and crisp!)

4. "I've heard it won't run at all if you don't have an internet connection." Phooey.  It runs fine, it just isn't connected to the internet.  GoogleDocs has an offline mode and once you're connected again, it automatically updates for you.

Last couple points - make sure that the first time you set it up you have WiFi access.  Ideally, one where you don't have to have full credentials (user name AND password) like I did on campus.  That part was a little tricky.  Once it boots up for the first time, it's really easy to get connected, but I wish it would boot up completely *before* you had to hook it up to wireless.

You won't be able to download printer drivers because those are set up for Windows/Mac.  You CAN login to Google on a computer that DOES have the driver and it serves as a sort of printer router for the Chromebook.  Setting it up was SHOCKINGLY simple and worked the very first time.  And, obviously, since all your documents are in the cloud, you could just log into another computer and print from there.  ALSO, Google has some CloudPrint ready printers, so if you are also looking to buy a printer at this time, I'd say do it in conjunction if at all possible.

I promise you won't regret this laptop.

I have used an Apple computer of some sort since they came out. My old Macbook was showing the signs of imminent death and so I was planning on buying a MacBook Air. After looking at the iPads, I was (understandably) not impressed with the screen on the Samsung. Still, I tried it. The keyboard seemed really nice, nicer than the one on my MacBook. The touchpad, though a bit small for my taste, seemed responsive. The fact that it was plastic escaped me until I read a review. Oh, it's "fake aluminum!" Well, I don't care. It's a nicely designed machine. But, I didn't buy it then. I went home to research and think about whether I would be happy with using Chrome and no programs.

So, I analyzed my computer usage for about a week and made the plunge. At $248, it seemed like a decent risk. After all, I've been spending almost a thousand dollars every three years for the latest Mac (yes, that's how long they've all lasted me). If I wound up using the Chromebook for a short while, or only when I'm out, it wouldn't be the worst thing in the world.

I've had the machine for a week now, and I'm thrilled. I love a good deal, and the Chromebook is that. No, it doesn't have a gorgeous screen. It looks kinda grainy (and yes, I know that's not tech talk). However, I have discovered that a matte screen is easier on my eyes, and so I'm glad. The keyboard is indeed very nice; the keys are big, and there's just the right amount of "bounce" for my taste. There's some odd spacing issues for some keyboard shortcuts, but I assume I'll get used to them.

I could care less that it's plastic. It doesn't have a plastic feel, and it is a very nice design. I wish the keyboard could be backlit when needed, but at this price, I won't quibble.

I expected it to just be Chrome, but there's a nice files manager if one plugs in a hard drive or thumb drive. There's enough Google apps to do most jobs I need to do. MS Office online is a bit too "lite" for me, but I expect I'll manage. I don't use any specialized software for my work.

The only serious complaint I have is that Bluetooth doesn't work on speakers right now. Really? I have to plug them in? That's a serious oversight that Google ought to fix asap.

But still, this computer is a great deal, and I'm tickled that I didn't spent much money on it. It seems ridiculous to spend $750 more to get a MacBook Air. That's what I'm comparing this to. This computer is light, stylish, easier than heck to use, doesn't use Windows (thank goodness), and has some really lovely OS touches that took this ex-Mac user less than an hour to figure out.

If you're looking for a computer to get online with, to bring on trips, and don't use Photoshop, or CAD/CAM, or any other "serious" programs, look no further for your next computer. It'll make you feel smart that you saved so much money. Go out and spent the rest of something totally frivolous. Me? I don't need an aluminum chassis machine. This is a tool for the mind, not an automobile.

So, with a few problems, 5 stars (easily)! If the screen was better & Google fixed the Bluetooth issue, I'd give it ten stars. Oh yeah, I can't. One last thing: the ports are in the back. It's an odd design choice, but even with that. . .five stars!

I wrote this somewhere else but have decided to append it here:

I don't know why I'm writing this since it's sold out but maybe some things that bug me can help someone make a purchasing decision in the event it comes back into stock.
It's a Chromebook - it will do all the things people have said in other reviews.
One thing people have focused on in the reviews published in the trade, here or Amazon is the build quality: it's fine. It flexes a lot becaused it's not machined aluminum but weighs little because the lack of being overbuilt. Some people associate this with being cheap, but the litmus test is it's ability to withstand a pouding by school kids, primary through college, while still keep ticking. After all 22% of the school districts in the US use this same model.
The screen - it's true, it's merely adequate. I have old eyes; coming from my Nexus 7 to this requires some adjustment. Frankly the app icons in the launch bar don't have much resolution, rendering them sloppily and cheapening the look. Functionally it works, but...
As a workaround I plug this thing into my HDTV and it works great, but some pictures look, frankly, better on this screen due to the way it handles highlights, which can blow out on the big screen. Additionally this is my second Samsung with the same issue as the first - namely the HDMI cord jiggles lose, sometimes when merely walking by the computer. This may be an issue with the cable, not sure.
What's really nice about the trackpad layout is it's centered so inadvertent touches don't happen, nor is it heat sensitive, a problem I had with a previous trackpad in which hover a palm over it would cause the cursor to tab!
There are shortcuts you must learn to get the most out of it: ctrl+alt+? will overlap an entire map onto whatever you're doing to make quick work of that learning process. Please note ALT+SEARCH is the caps lock. Just hit it again to toggle off.
If you really don't trust the cloud but like the functionality of this machine you can easily configure a personal cloud via a wifi storage device or and old fashioned usb hard drive, which are dirt cheap.
Chromebooks are basically dummy terminals, meaning if you have to return it or give it away you can easily go into Settings to Powerwash the machine to restore it to its native state. Imagine doing that with a PC or Mac.
As for form factor I think it's nearly perfect, especially since it's a MacBook Air clone, but something that is bothersome is the sharp leading edge. It should be beveled. Not a problem normallly, doesn't affect typing. It's when you're in cruise the web mode, slouched on couch lazily track padding your way around - that's when you feel it.
I'm a power user: 12-15 tabs open (for reading later. Otherwise easy to forget), rdio, Google Satellite (or Earth on a PC), windows justified left and right, etc. These ARM processors while fanlessly silent, just aren't powerful enough for me. The one in my Nexus 7 suffers the same fate. Anyway I'm just being nitpicky here.
I'd gladly pay more for a machine with more RAM, Haswell, great screen, good build quality, more rigid body structure, same form factor and weight. After all realistically the things that will fail on a Chromebook in the future are hardware-related; the OS should be just as fast as when new for years to come. I'm sure that's in the works already, seeing as how quickly folks are cottoning to the basic machines. Something like a MacBook Air with an HD screen running ChromeOS.

Edit: I just ran the HDMI in reverse orientation from previously, seemed to seat much better, though I'll refrain from doing so since laptop usage puts a little strain on the connector.

Simultaneously I was streaming radio in a tab while uploading files from an attached storage device to the cloud...man the thing got hot!  While browser tabs didn't want to refresh without sneezing rdio only stutter, briefly, once and upload speed seemed unaffected. But I did see little flames shoot out the vents...joke.

Google advertises these as a supplementary laptop, and I think that is a mistake. There is no reason not use this as a primary laptop for 90% of people. I think that there are a lot of misunderstanding concerning Chrome OS that are limiting the sales of these. In addition there are several things aspects of Mac and Windows PCs that people are not willing to break away from due to a brainwashing of advertisements. I am a firm believer that people should use what works for them, so please don't look at me as a snob. I would like to address some ideas that I have heard tossed around by electronics consumers, because many of these ideas are misleading.

1. This computer is not powerful enough for my use!
So many people are used to seeing Intel core i5's sold in PCs, that the idea of any weaker processor will make their machine useless. This is simply false, I can stream videos online and use multiple apps simultaneously. Windows PCs need strong processors and more RAM because they are running so many background processes as part of the operating system. For the ChromeOS, there is no need for so much horsepower. (although new Chromebooks (Acer C720, HP 14) do offer this)

2. I need Microsoft Word and Excel! If I don't have these I can't do my work!
You can use FREE WEBAPP VERSIONS OF MICROSOFT WORD AND EXCEL ON SKYDRIVE.LIVE.COM. For whatever reason, nobody knows about this. If you have never tried these before, I strongly encourage you to open a new tab and go to skydrive.live.com right now and sign up. These are free versions of Microsoft Software, produced by Microsoft  available at no charge. I understand that documents need to be created in the Microsoft format, but for personal use only docs, I have come to prefer Google Docs formats because they are lightweight applications. I only see the tools I actually use in the applications.

3. I don't want to be online at all times! Google is going to steal my information!
This is so crazy I won't even address it. If you really feel this way, then stop looking at Chromebooks because nobody is going to be able to sell you on them.

4. 16 GB on-board storage is not enough!
I will admit i was worried about switching to Cloud Storage, but Google Drive has been an excellent choice for me personally. I use many different computers throughout my day, and I have all my files with me once I sign into Chrome. If you have ever lost a flash drive before, you know my pain. With Google Drive, your data will never corrupt, and you will never lose your data. You may think that you do not have internet access at all times, but try to think of the last time you wanted to work on a file and you didn't have a wifi connection. the only time I have felt this is commuting to work, and driving long distances. If you use these times to work on documents then you will have to set your documents to be available offline.

5. I use specific software that only runs on Windows!
This is the only real reason I have ever heard not to buy a Chromebook. I understand plenty of people use Windows software to perform their work. This obviously won't be available for your Chromebook. However, ChromeRDP allows you to remote to any Windows PC. I use this frequently to remote to my work PC from home, and it is so easy to use.

6. For only $250, this hardware must be junk!
My Samsung Chromebook has had no issued so far, and I rarely hear of screen problems. The 16 GB SSD is almost invincible. These new SolidStateDrives are not like old, noisy, harddrives that would frequently break. With no moving parts in the laptop, we will see that hardware problems will be very very rare. Plus, Samsung is a high-quality hardware manufacturer so you should not be worried about this.

My Rating of several Aspects:
Processor and RAM Performance: 3/5
  These are not designed to be maximum power PCs, but the chipset included is definitely sufficient for all of my needs.

Screen: 3/5
  The matte finish reduces glare, but I do miss the glossy finish that is so common now.

Keyboard: 4/5
  This is the best keyboard I have ever typed on, including Mac keyboards. The chiclet style keys are excellent and I type through essays quickly with few errors.

Structural Sturdiness: 4/5
  This is not the anodized aluminum that Macs are known for, no matter how visually similar it looks. But the strength of the case on this computer is impressive and competes with any <$600 laptop.

Design: 5/5
  This thing is great for a lightweight laptop that you can take anywhere. I bought a caselogic sleeve for about $15 and I can throw this in my backpack with books and anything else and never worry about it breaking.

FINAL NOTE: THE NEW ACER C720 IS A MORE POWERFUL VERSION OF THIS SAMSUNG MODEL FOR THE SAME PRICE THAT I WOULD RECOMMEND TO ANYONE. ALSO DO NOT WORRY ABOUT THE RISKS OF BUYING ANY CHROMEBOOK USED. THEY ARE EASILY RESET TO FACTORY SETTINGS.

I can check email, listen to music, work on servers remotely via SSH or Chrome RDP, write essays with Google docs or the FREE MICROSOFT WORD AND EXCEL on skydrive.live.com that nobody seems to know about. These are free editions of Microsoft Office software produced by Microsoft. And you can access all your work from anywhere with free storage space on Skydrive. If you don't k=know about these, check them out.

OK I have been using Windows computers and laptops for years, but I was on a much tighter budget this time, so I thought I would give this a try. GOOD SIDE:

 SUPERFAST startup/shut down.

BAD SIDE:

UPDATE:

There is an app for nearly everything that you could possibly hope to do with a "normal computer." Google Docs, Google Sheets, and Google Slides take care of Microsoft Office. Pixlr editor is a free photo-editing app that has about 85% of the capability of Adobe Photoshop- and it's free. Tons of productivity and business apps. If you have an Android smartphone and are utilizing any of the Google apps such as Drive, Keep, Gmail, Maps, Calendars, you will find that all of your stuff syncs up beautifully between your phone and your Chromebook. You also get 100gb of Drive storage space for free for 2 years when you purchase your Chromebook, which is more than I will personally ever need. In short, if you aren't a fan of Google, need an optical drive for some reason, or feel the need to download every program that you have to use or use specific programs that there are no alternatives to, this may not be the computer for you. I would definitely recommend being INCREDIBLY careful with this machine. The finish on the Chromebook feels nice and it is incredibly lightweight, but because of it's cheap price, it seems like some of the materials used on this are also very cheap. This is definitely meant to be taken around frequently, but you still want to be careful when carrying it around. I had read online before purchasing this that it had problems connecting with wi-fi at times. So far, there have been 2 or 3 separate occasions where the wi-fi suddenly dropped. This was fixed by a simple reboot, but hopefully it doesn't happen too many more times. Also, if you know you are not going to be using your Chromebook for an extended period of time, be sure you shut it down completely, not just close the lid and let it sleep. This will drain the battery significantly opposed to actually shutting down the Chromebook. Another con of this machine is the battery meter. The percentage is accurate, but the "time left" meter is not always very accurate and changes frequently. However, once you begin using this machine more often you get used to that.

Again, this is a great machine for what it is, not what it isn't. It is not at all a replacement for a power user who is used to a Windows or Apple OS. But if you want something to take around with you to surf the web on, I would recommend it for that, just remember to be careful with it.

I've been using computers since 1979 and now at 72 Im using a Samsung 11.3 Chromebook and the whole Google Chrome OS experience.  At 250 bucks its a great deal for what it does because it does it flawlessly, with minor exceptions.  The Chromebook size is almost perfect as a convenient door into the internet.  At about the size of a pad of paper it has all you need.  All the positive marketing points of the machine and Google Chrome OS system are true. For the majority of the population it fills our needs and is as simple as it gets.  If you use MS Internet Explorer the first thing you will notice is Google Chrome has eliminated every annoying attribute MS-IE ever invented.  Be honest with yourself and think about what you really do on your personal home computer.  If you feel the need for a Microsoft OS along with all the annoying security and daily updates in addition to the same for MS Office on a 1500 buck desktop maybe you should consider incorporating your family and hiring an IT guy too.  Personally I feel Google is the future of internet computing for the world.

As to the negative aspects of using the Chromebook as my go to computer.  After three weeks of using the Samsung 11.3" Chromebook the screen is still difficult to see and hard on my eyes.  Adjustments have been made for larger fonts and color changes have been made on some reading materials.  Could be because this reviewer wears bifocal eye glasses but its more than that.  There just isn't much real estate to move things around especially when it comes to photos.  The clarity of the screen just doesn't pop out at you as would be the case in the Chromebook Pixel (Im assuming).  However more to the point is the color or contrast on some web pages.  An example is Google Calendar,  the type just doesn't have good contrast.. One major problem on some web pages is the page does not fit on the screen.  Im not a web designer so  Im not sure where the problem is, the web, the Chromebook or Google. An example: I was on the Delta Airline reservations site and I could not use it to make my reservations because some of the page was overlaid and jumbled.  Same problems happened on many other sites where you have selection options in ordering things.

Again, for the 250 bucks delivered into your house it is a steal.  It is really the perfect recliner companion for wireless surfing the web and general research/entertainment needs. Plus Google has so many apps you could spend the rest of your life just setting those up for whatever.

I purchased the Samsung Wi-Fi Chromebook because I needed something fast and portable. I have a large powerful Windows-running laptop for work so I didn't need another PC. I also satisfied my need for something Apple with an iPhone 4S (but I will be upgraded to the Samsung Galaxy Note 3 when my contract is up at the end of the year. Sorry, Apple, I don't want your ugly gold iPhone.) ANYWAY. I love this Chromebook. It is the best deal for the price. If you looking for a computer to give a teenager or a college kid it's great for that. Transferring between Google Docs and Microsoft Word (or the other programs) is simple, so that's not an excuse to not buy the Chromebook. It takes some time getting used to how everything runs but once you get it it is simple. If you love keyboard shortcuts, the Chromebook is full of them. This machine is versatile and sleek (it really looks like a MacBook Air but is a fraction of the cost). It is very light and portable. It has a good battery life and charges quickly. If you're already using Google Chrome as your browser, doing typical internet things is exactly the same.
Things I Do With The Chromebook:
-Watch TV/Netflix. Unplug the HDMI cable from your cable box and put it in the Chromebook. You can mirror the screens or use the TV as a second monitor. Anyway, I can stream movies quickly right on to the TV.
-Listen to music. I have a two Bluetooth speakers and the Chromebook connects right to them. With the Pandora app, you're good to rock out.
-Work. I can create docs using Google's apps, save them to the drive and then open them on my PC in a Microsoft program if necessary.
-Social media stuff. It's the same as on a traditional computer.
I know I'm not using the device to its full potential and there are so many more uses and applications. The reps at a Best Buy are great and will talk to you about how to make the Chromebook do what you want it to do.
I'm pretty sure I will be purchasing two more Chromebooks during the holiday season (on Amazon).

Because I'm really reviewing too different products, the physical Samsung netbook and the Chrome OS, I'll separate my review.

Samsung Netbook

Pros
- Keyboard is big enough for even large hands.
- Netbook is thin, light weight
- Battery life is around 7-9 hours, depending on use
- Screen is large enough for most work, but small enough to be portable
- Contains a decent webcam
- Excellent price - you can't beat $249.00

Cons
- Only two USB ports
- No old-fashioned monitor ports, so I can't connect this netbook to most projectors at my school
- Keyboard sometimes strains my small hands because it's almost too large
- No delete key (backspace sometimes works for this)
- No capslock key

Chrome OS

Pros
- Instant boot, which is really quite awesome
- Very little to no bloatware
- East to use, no setup
- The Play Store has a lot of really innovative apps that can make one's life easier

Cons
(where do I even start?)
- No Dropbox integration

Let me explain what I mean by this. Yes, I can pin the dropbox WEBSITE to the taskbar and instant it easily (kind of like an easily accessible bookmark), but using it on this laptop is difficult and tedious. To get a file from dropbox, I must download it, which downloads to my computer's hard drive. Then, I have to upload it into Drive. If I try to open it right away, however, I can't edit. It opens it into a Viewer app which is the most unhelpful and irritating app on this device. So, I must open it manually into the Sheets app, which will let me edit. Then, after editing, I have to download the file as a proper .xls/.doc/.ppt to my computer's hard drive. This inevitably changes the file name, which I then have to manually rename so that it will replace the original file when I upload it to dropbox. Then, go back to the dropbox site and upload it, and it then syncs with my other devices. And of course the formatting is changed, so when I open it elsewhere, I either have to deal with ugly formatting or change it before I can use the document.

Yes, I could use Drive, but this brings me to the next annoying part of Chrome OS:

- Every file must be changed to Google's native file types before they can be added to Drive or used in any way

This just adds another unnecessary step to everything, whether I want to upload to Dropbox or send the file to someone else.

- Google Office apps are just inferior

They are difficult to use, they unnecessarily have different file extensions that must be changed to use with Microsoft Office programs, and the formatting never looks as nice. There are also fewer options.

- Every app requires internet connectivity to work fully

For some reason, Google decided it would be a great idea to limit the functionality of its apps if the computer isn't connected to the internet. This means that if I'm making a slideshow online, I can't add a picture to my slides whatsoever. Even though I made to sure to add the image files to my computer the night before so that I could make the slideshow while I was at work where I am not lucky enough to have internet. Why? It makes no sense whatsoever.

So, in summary, that's why I gave this review three stars. I'm very impressed with the Samsung netbook, but not very impressed with the Chrome OS. I'm currently looking into trying to have the option to boot to Ubuntu as well, because Chrome OS unnecessarily limits my productivity and creates unnecessary barriers to smooth operations I performs everyday.

I never thought I would buy a laptop with no hard drive. I did. And it's wonderful. So everything you do has to be done via the Cloud. Specifically Google Docs, Spreadsheet and Presentation  now all part of Google Drive. Music and Photos can be enjoyed through the machine once added to Google+ or Drive.

The other catch is it is largely a WIFI machine. You can link it by wire to your internet modem and there is a 3G/WIFI version but if you have WIFI in the house or visit Starbucks, McDonalds or live in a digitally connected town, it works wonderfully. I don't do a lot of heavy lifting on the computer  don't crunch numbers, don't play involved games, etc. Just email, browse and write. And this is a laptop that fits those needs.

The best catch: It cost $249.

I bought four of these for four girls, ages 12-16. They are mostly used for video chatting, watching videos, and doing Khan Academy exercises (in addition to general-purpose web browsing, of course).

The Chromebooks are easy to use, and it's very convenient that they're tied to their google accounts - any girl can log in on any Chromebook and still see their own bookmarks, Google Docs, etc.

Setup was trivially easy, and I liked that I could "power wash" them to reset them to factory condition before handing them out.

Battery life is good. 6-8 hours of use from a single charge, at least initially.

The non-standard keyboards took some getting used to, but are a good decision in hindsight (removing seldom-used function keys, instead replacing them with brightness/volume/etc).

I would not buy one for myself, unless I was going to dual-boot with Ubuntu. There are a few things I need to do daily that can't be done in a web browser.

Edit: After almost a year, one of these has a broken charging jack, and another has a smashed screen from a one meter drop. Although the Chrome OS is still going strong, I probably would not buy this model again. Accordingly, I have reduced my initial five-star review to three.

I bought the Chromebook for the wife.  She always dreads when I install a new or updated Linux distribution on her laptop. With a few tweaks to the standard setup, within a week, she was happily surfing away and no longer needed my help.  The battery lasts for hours.  Startup is nearly instantaneous.  Ever so often, the system will download the updates, and with a quick reboot, the Chromebook is up-to-date.  It is all very uneventful.

She finds the keyboard comfortable and easy to use.  Since she prefers a mouse to the trackpad, I just installed the nano-receiver from a M305 wireless mouse, and the system instantly recognized it.

My only complaint with the Chromebook is the reliance on Google's cloudprint service for printing.  I would have much preferred to see the system use CUPS printing as is typical for most Linux or Unix based computers.  Other than this one issue, I am very pleased with the product.  I deducted one star because of this "feature".

I will start by saying that I have two desktop PCs that I use for the heavy duty stuff, but I've always had a laptop for mostly web browsing and chatting with friends.  I previously had a Macbook Air that recently died a bit prematurely, so I thought I would give this Chromebook a shot.

Firstly, I really like the size of the laptop.  It's very small and lightweight, and yet the keyboard and trackpad feel really good.  I am very picky about my laptop trackpads, having been spoiled by my Air.  Most Windows laptops have horrible trackpads and I was very concerned about going to this one.  However, the accuracy is excellent and the gestures are pretty good.  I don't think they are quite up to par with the Macs, but for this price point the trackpad is better than Windows laptops that are three times this price.

As far as the operating system itself, color me impressed.  I was a user of Google Chrome already and heavily invested into Google web apps, so that transition wasn't hard at all.  I did find myself looking for some viable Chrome-based alternatives to software that I used on my PC, like a VNC client.  To date, I haven't found a single piece of software that I need on a daily basis on a laptop that doesn't have a Chrome app for it.

The only negative thing I can say is that the ARM processor in this guy can sometimes get a little sluggish on graphically intensive pages, but mostly it's smooth.  High definition video is just fine most of the time, but some pages can still slow it down to a crawl.  I have tweaked a couple of settings and blocked some web elements from loading and that seemed to improve it greatly.  I definitely recommend this Samsung Chromebook and Chrombooks in general.  I will probably grab another one when the Haswell updates come out.

I just finished a graduate program and have used this for over a year now, as a student, a job-seeker, an employee, and just for random daily tasks. I'll speak personally from how this has helped me in my specific situation, in case there is someone who may be in a similar situation.

There are a few things about me that made me a great fit for this product:

1) I own a desktop computer

There are some things I need a desktop for, and I have a desktop computer for those occasions. Interestingly, one of the things I learned is how little I really needed my desktop. I packed it away and didn't bother unpacking it for two months now. If anything it's probably a good thing that I can't play video games on this thing, so if you're a recovered game addict with relapsing tendencies (like yours truly), that's something to consider. But there are some things I'll definitely need the desktop for, such as photo editing, which I will eventually need to unpack the desktop to do.

2) I use Google everything (gmail, drive, calendar, etc.)

And so do a lot of my friends, making it very easy to work on Google and share my work with others. The suite of Google office products are pretty handy, and for most uses is more than sufficient. Because google docs do not count against your size limit on Google Drive, it feels like unlimited storage to me, and I've done just fine without any additional storage.

3) I use Amazon Prime (mainly for movies, Kindle books)

The vast majority of "apps" that you can add on the chromebook do little more than provide you a link, turning the bottom bar into a glorified "favorites" bar. The kindle is one exception, since you are able to download books for offline reading. Since I watch all my movies through Amazon Prime, it's not a big deal that there's no DVD player.

4) I intend to carry this around all over the place

This is ideal for carrying around because it's light and thin (I just leave it in my bag and I never think "dang it, I shouldn't have brought my laptop today") the battery life is great (I never really have to bring the charger unless I forgot to charge it the night before) and it's cheap (I've dropped it and I've dropped the bag it's in many times, but it hasn't broken yet, and I wouldn't be totally bummed as I would be if I dropped some other really expensive thin light laptop).

5) The places I go have wifi anyway

Starbuck's, McDonald's, school, library, etc. In my neighborhood there are a lot of places to go for free wifi.

A few reasons why this product was not a good fit:

1) Skydrive is not that good.

This isn't Google's fault, but it does affect my review of whether or not you should buy this chromebook, because the chromebook is only as good as the apps that what it can run in the browser. The truth is that Skydrive is nowhere close to the much more robust Google Drive. It technically does a lot of the same things, and in some ways it is indeed better than Google drive at handling MS Office documents, but I've had too many instances where the website would fail and I would lose something I had been working on. No matter how many bells and whistles it has, the fact that it can't reliably work on things has made me lose hope on skydrive, so now if I really want to fine-tune a MS Office document, I have to find a PC.

2) It's kind of weak sauce.

It's okay with most things, and I can watch movies on it full-screen, but sometimes it's just slow, especially if you have a lot of tabs open. I've learned to be a lot more disciplined about tab-closing, and that's helped, but at some point the thing is just slow, and when I'm trying to work with two windows at the same time, scheduling things and responding to e-mails and such, there's a slight lag that will make things take longer than they would otherwise.

CONCLUSION:
If you're a no-frills kind of person and you're looking for something like this, then I recommend it, especially if you're broke like me. It doesn't have a lot of (or any, really) bells or whistles, but it can get quite a bit done. The times are a-changin', and as the cloud expands in the size and diversity of products they offer, this will become even more useful over time.

We were so excited to switch out entire company over to Chromebooks.  I thought that I did a lot of research, but I was wrong.  First of all, these little babies are sweet.  Super fast computing and boot-up, really neat "bells and whistles"...if you are using as your home computer, I would recommend it as a GREAT alternative to a Macbook.  That is why I give it 5 stars, because their utility is great, just not for business.  But seeing that we were transitioning our company to the ChromeBook's there are some major concerns that need to be addressed before you think about making the dive.

1. Any website that was built for Internet Explorer (you will know by trying to use the site in Google Chrome, without using any extensions, and the site acts funny), will not work in the Chromebook.  We were under the impression the IE Tab and other extensions like this, would remedy the problem.  They wont, at all. Those extensions were only built for Windows based operating systems that you use Chrome as your primary search engine.  I even spoke to a product specialist with Google Apps, and he even said that there are ZERO options for me out there, even with a ton of research after I spoke to him, any of the programs are very slow if they offer any utility at all.  So, in closing, any websites built of IE WILL NOT be available to work in using the Chrome Book.

2. Using Adobe is a nightmare.  We use Adobe Pro everyday and we use Adobe reader for EVERY SINGLE document.  It is beat down to open a PDF (a three step process) and the alternative to Adobe Pro is a very weak counterpart.  I imagine that Adobe will produce a ChromeBook app, which will be a work around, but until then, don't attempt, it takes too much time to do the step-by-step process to make it attempt to be as useful as Adobe Pro.

3. We use dual monitors, which is a productivity booster, so I was excited to see that the ChromeBook supported that, but what they don't tell you is that there is NO WAY to close the lid to the ChromeBook  with out the computer going into sleep mode.  This is a bit of a pain because you lose a lot of space now having an open laptop on your desk.

All in all, great computer if you don't regularly use word, excel or pdf's.  Seeing that Google Chrome works on about 95% of sites out there, then rest assured that you will be in good shape with the computer as a home computer...great utility!

I love this product. I work as a freelance writer while attending grad school and this Chromebook fits my needs. It's quick and allows me to multitask smoothly. I still have my traditional laptop, but that is primarily so I can open Word docs and print.

I highly recommend.

The Long Version:

Let me start this off by saying that I am quickly able to adapt to new technologies, as I am a tech fanatic. If you do not adapt to change well/quickly, your mileage may vary with the Samsung Chromebook.

I ordered this particular machine because it is capable of doing all of the things that a beginning college student needs, and for the least amount of money. The things I consider "needs" are the ability to take notes, edit documents, create documents, and access online content (yes the Chromebook supports Flash Player).

Typical User Experience Summary:
My experience with the Chromebook has been quite pleasant after one week of use. I have gotten accustomed to the Internet-based applications, and enjoy them on my college's free Wi-Fi network each day I have class. I take notes with the Scratchpad app in my Math, English, Psychology and History classes and my notes are immediately backed up to Google Drive after any modification to a document. No hassle with the usual File-> Save As that you experience in Windows or Mac OS X. After each edit or addition to a document, the Chromebook will sync and back up any document you are working with and you can just close it when you're finished. While the Chromebook cannot load an install of Microsoft Office for Word, PowerPoint, or Excel, you CAN edit MS Office documents in the free web-based application called Google Docs, which is free to anyone with a Google account (you don't even need a Chromebook to use Google Docs).

Technical Information:
I usually get 1.5 days of use on a single charge with medium-high brightness settings, and I am very pleased with these results. The internal ARM CPU/GPU combo keeps the laptop running pretty cool, with the occasional warm feeling after extended amounts of use (make note of WARM, not HOT). The display is clear and of good quality at 1366x768 resolution, and the brightness settings are varied enough to suit anyone's preferences with a quick adjustment from the Brightness keys on the top of the keyboard.

Short Version:

The impressive stuff:
-battery life is fantastic, easily 1-1.5 days of life on a single charge if you don't max out the brightness 24/7
-boot time is around 5-7 seconds, shut down time about the same if not a little quicker
-all of the included FREE Google software runs excellently, quick and easy to pick up in one sitting
-most of the Google apps can sync with Android devices should there be an Android version of the application i.e. Chrome Browser, Google Drive, Gmail, Google Calendar, Google Keep, Google Play Music, etc.
-can handle quite a few Browser tabs open with little performance drop
-laptop runs cool, rarely gets a little warm. Never gets hot to the touch.

The (minor) disappointments:
-HD video playback in YouTube is just not possible. It is choppy, and will eventually freeze to the point of just audio running. Must play YouTube videos at 360/480p to get a steady and easily viewable stream.
-No LED backlighting on the keyboard keys. Just realized how useful a feature like this would be, as I am typing this review in the dark while watching a movie.
-the build seems to be very cheap, all plastic. But what can you expect from a $250 laptop.

I got Chromebook specifically for graduate school.  My husband just picked one up for college. We both already have access to a PC with Microsoft Office through our gaming laptops and also available for use at school and the local library.  For us, this is a supplementary device that we both plan to use specifically for note-taking, internet browsing, school email to communicate with professors and classmates, accessing course materials, reading and researching PDF articles, and word processing via Google Drive.

Chromebook might be the right device for you IF you meet one or more of the following:

- low or basic tech needs - internet browsing, use of online apps
- already using Google products such as Gmail/familiarity with their products
- basic use of word processing, spreadsheets, presentations
- you will be in an area with free wifi whenever you plan to use this device (home, school, library, coffee shop, etc.)
- you plan for Chromebook to be a supplementary or secondary device (read: you already have a computer or access to a computer at home)
- you are open minded and willing to try new things!

Chromebook is 2.4 pounds, has approximately 6 hours of battery life, and is fun and easy to use.  It is smaller than my clipboard and fits in my backpack right between my notebooks and textbooks.  The weight, long battery life, and quick boot and shutdown time (seriously, it is up and running in SECONDS) make this an awesome computer for students.

Although Chromebook is extremely portable, it is not necessarily a good fit for a frequent traveler that does not have access to reliable wifi.  Nor is it a good fit for someone that actually NEEDS to run the full suite of Microsoft Office or other programs.  It is not a gaming laptop.  Let's be honest though, most people just use computers for email, web browsing, and visiting various social media sites.  If that sounds like you then I think you should give Chromebook a try!

If you are a student, I highly recommend Chromebook as your primary machine for school.  If you really are worried about the fact that you will not have access to MS office or other specific programs then I recommend that you check with your school library or computer lab to see if the programs are available there.  If so then I wouldn't hesitate to pick up Chromebook.

I have had my Samsung for a month and love it. There are some key items to understand. You need to know what this device does, what it doesn't, and don't try to compare it to something it can not compete with. Want a $2000 Macbook? Then don't expect a $240 Chromebook to be the same and review it poorly based on that.

This is a $240 device that operates way beyond what should be expected. I use this mainly for school as well, and have not hit one snag in daily use. I do not need it to do high end graphics, video or anything else. I am a sophisticated user with 20+ years of experience. Here are some things I do daily, often all at the same time: Tumblr, reddit, Evernote, Google drive, gmail, Outlook 365, Kindle cloud reader, spotify, facebook, linkedin, Westlaw (work specific application), text editor, adn hootsuite. Here is a quick rundown of what works and the few lacking items:

PROS
- This thing is LIGHT. I carry it around, open, in the library while doing legal research without blinking. It is easily a one handed device. Think tablet....with a keyboard.
- The keyboard. The biggest beef in the world is that laptops can have a seriously sketchy keyboard. This one is springy, tight, and responsive. Very nice.
- Yes you need to be online, but everything I have needed has an offline feature. Document editing, storage, Chrome apps, Evernote. You are not as limited as you might think
- Battery. WOW. This thing pounds at 6-8 hours easy without charging.
- Ports. Two USB (one is 3.0), and HDMI (are you kidding me?) SD slot, and headphones. Perfect.
- Screen. Honestly, for the money, the screen is great. It is very solid quality and is plenty bright enough (although lowering brightness extends the battery even more)
- Wireless. Wireless is not a universal truth. Some wireless devices have awful ability to pick up signals. I have areas that are known wireless black holes for my phone and other devices. This has a fantastic ability to connect and hold a signal. Very impressed.
- There have been reports of the track pad having poor reaction. I have not seen that at all. In fact, the track pad has gestures and is responsive for me.

CONS
- Keyboard. I only wish the keyboard had a backlight. I think that should actually be universal!
- Track pad. The track pad is fine, but it is a bit loud when you click. I mean LOUD! Otherwise it is fine.
- Speed. I am not sure I can complain about this, but the device is a bit laggy. I know. I know. $240. Still, it is a hair slow on response sometimes. I am reaching here.
- SD slot. The SD card slot is a great feature and I was excited to triple my local space with a 32 GB card, however, the design of this slot is not good. The card literally sticks out almost 3/4 an inch. I was hoping for it to house into the laptop and I would never see it.

Overall, I recommend this device to EVERYONE. I have already slated to get one for my daughter for Christmas and speak to people daily who notice it. It works great, especially at this price point and I honestly do not worry about it much. All my work is automatically backed up due to its nature and I can access everything I need. Think about it. Depending on how mobile you are, you consistently have to think about protecting your $3,000 Macbook from damage or being stolen. I never worry about this with my great Chromebook. I mean, why even add bulk with a case? Who cares? I highly recommend this product.

If I may let me say a few words too about not specifically the hardware, but rather why I decided to buy Samsung Chromebook and why now. Many of you may agree, right now it is a terrible time to buy any kind of PC including notebooks.  Haswell on the way, revision of Windows 8 at the cornel, SSD mounted ultrabooks on the rise that cost thousand or more and of course the buzz around Chrome OS uncertain with its Packaged Apps direction.  So, why did I decide to buy a Chromebook and picked Samsung? For the Chromebook a single, most darn good reason is security. I am still using Windows XP and I prefer to use free programs to do things, like You Tube downloader, file type converter, media player and so on. I bought the Chromebook for my first year of graduate school as a supplemental computer to my HP Pavilion laptop. I was worried about bringing my $1000 laptop to lab since I'm a Microbiology Masters student. The last thing I wanted was to get some bacteria or deadly virus on my laptop and have to worry about sterilizing it, or spilling buffer all over the laptop and have it short-circuit. Instead, the Chromebook, a much cheaper alternative built around saving everything to the Cloud, will be taking its place. The first thing to realize is, this is NOT a full-spec performance PC. But I didn't buy it to act as such so I was more than impressed with the Chromebook for these reasons:

Pros:
- 9+ hours of battery life (if brightness isn't all the way up. My record is 9.5 hours so far of class time use)
- Responsive keyboard (doesn't feel too cheap, keys can take a good beating)
- Quick to start up and good processor (don't expect it to have stunning graphics or console quality game capabilities, but it's perfect for note taking and presentations)
- Small and lightweight (fits very easily into a draw-string backpack)
- Rather robust construction (being clumsy, I accidentally dropped this within the first week of getting it. Despite the 5 foot fall, it only suffered a single minor scratch and was otherwise completely okay. I wouldn't recommend dropping it every day, but good to know it can take an occasional bump or drop)
- Extra storage capacity (the 16GB built-in is nice for papers, but any pictures or movies would bog down it's small solid state HD. The free 100GB Google Drive storage is very handy! Once that offer expires, I plan on getting a 64GB SD card that will just remain in the expansion slot 24/7)

Cons:
- I made the mistake of uploading powerpoints from one of my lectures to Google Drive without converting them to Google's format. When I got to class, I could only view the powerpoint and could not edit or access the note function at the bottom of the slides. I had assumed that it would open in Google Slides or convert it automatically but I was unable to convert the slides on the Chromebook. (The conversion problem could have been a result of the school's internet, which I swear is from the stone age, as downloading a 14MB file takes 5+ minutes, so I'm sure converting it via Google Drive takes about the same time). Lesson learned, make sure you have the important files converted to Google's format prior to heading to your meeting/class.

Overall, you get an excellent machine for around $250. It isn't meant to compete with a full time desktop PC or a performance laptop, but it doesn't need to. It by far beats out any laptop in battery life, and is on par in terms of keyboard functionality and word processing capabilities. I've more than enjoyed it so far this semester, and I will keep you updated if I continue to love it throughout the school year.

Sometimes it loses the wifi connection, but that's a minor annoyance. Using a mouse helps navigation on the screen.

Some of the explanations on how to get things done could be expanded. Technical typesetting is difficult via the web.

These quibbles aside, I actually like this chromebook. Having the screen larger than on the iPad, with a real keyboard, and light enough to carry from one wifi spot to another makes it a good deal for the money.

The bad: I listen to a lot of music online while I browse and the sound quality is not as good as a full-blown, high quality laptop or tablet. I don't think most people would notice the lower quality of sound, but I did notice less "fullness" of sound when it was plugged into a stereo and into headphones when compared to iPads or my wife's Nexus 10. But I can buy TWO of these for the price of one of those! So that is a pretty specific and narrow "minus." Also: Chrome OS is limited to its own "app store." So it won't run games or other programs written for Windows, unless the publisher has created a version specifically for the Chrome OS. So a friend of mine who bought one to gain access to his work through a web page was out of luck because his employer's portal uses Java.

But for web browsing and casual music and news listening, I love this. It charges quickly and runs for a good long time on a charge. I use mine for over an hour a day, almost every day.

I was not sure what I wanted to purchase as far as a computer. I have a desk top at work and really do not have use for spreadsheets and microsoft programs at home. This is easy and user friendly. I would recommend it for anyone who just likes to browse the web.

If you understand the hardware and software limitations of ChromeOS (the operating system that Chromebooks run), I think this one of the best bargains in tech.  While there isn't much horsepower under the hood, the components are a good fit for the ChromeOS vision.  Performance is snappy.  The form factor is small, light, and extremely portable.  I'm pleased with the build quality for the price (though it still won't compare with anything that costs 3x as much).  Touchpad works well and has some multi-touch functionality (e.g. 2-finger scrolling).  The keyboard has a well-designed layout (nothing really funky) and is comfortable to type on (comparable to the chiclet keyboard on my Vaio F Series as well as Macbook Air and Pro keyboards).

I bought the Chromebook for grad school use in lieu of my 17 inch desktop replacement.  I'm a pretty heavy user of Google Drive (formerly Google Docs).  My use case is not tied to any software that requires a specific OS.  The Chromebook has been perfect for me for school use.  It's actually supplanted my Vaio for casual use when I don't need Windows-specific software or raw horsepower.  If you're interested in Ubuntu Linux, both Crouton and Chrubuntu are easy to install.

While I love my Chromebook, there are areas which will hopefully be improved in successive models.  The screen is one of the lowest quality panels on any contemporary laptop.  This is expected at this price point, but it's the only thing that consistently reminds me that I'm using a sub-$250 device.  From an aesthetic standpoint, the hinge where the screen meets the laptop body is a bit ugly compared to higher-end laptops.  I'm happier that the hinge seems structurally sound and works well, but it is a small nitpick.

Overall, I can't imagine being more pleased for such a low-priced computer.  There are definite limitations that should rule this computer out in many use cases, but it's a phenomenal value at what it does well.  If you're comfortable living almost entirely in the cloud, I don't know if there's a better value out there.  If you own a desktop or not-very-portable laptop and would like an ultraportable 2nd computer for light use, this Chromebook is a phenomenal complement.  If you want something cheap that won't be a disaster if it's lost, stolen, or dropped, $250 is about as little as you can pay for a computer.
