I love my new Samsung Chromebook. After one week of constant use, I am very pleased with my purchase. I would like to begin by saying that my "main" computer is a 15.5" Sony Vaio that dual-boots Ubuntu and LinuxMint. I am a student and was looking for something that would be a more portable as I run back and forth from home to university. I browsed the latest laptops at Best Buy and was not ready to commit to funding any of the new models I saw. Then, I came across the Chromebook section and decided $249 was a perfect price and it appeared that the machine had all the basic requirements I would need. To my great disappointment, Best Buy was sold out so I immediately came home and ordered one from amazon.

Who Should Buy a Chromebook?

Anyone who wants a more portable laptop and only needs a computer for writing documents, browsing the web or watching videos should really consider a Chromebook. Also, any first-time laptop owners who just want to do simple tasks would benefit from having a Chromebook because they are so easy to use and you do not have to worry about licences, updates or viruses. If you need specific software or play a lot of games, the Chromebook would not be a good replacement.

What I Like:

Set-up - Setting up a Chromebook is the easiest set up I have every gone through. If you have a google account, all you do is login using that information, select your wi-fi network and time zone and everything is ready for you. If you use the Chrome web browser, all of your tabs are synced.

Size - 11.6" seems so small compared to my 15.5" laptop, but the Chromebook's size makes it easily portable. The screen size has only been an issue on a few select website where I needed to adjust the page view, but otherwise I feel I adjusted very well to the smaller size.

Keyboard - The Chromebook's keyboard is one of its best features. I love typing on this little machine. The size of the keys and the space between the keys is perfect. Instead of function keys above the numbers, the Chromebook has smart keys to better navigate the Chrome browser. Also, screen and volume adjustment keys are in this same row, making controlling your machine a lot easier than trying to remember which function key does what. There is no page up or down keys, but a series of keyboard shortcuts found on the Chromebook's website will show you how to achieve those tasks.

Trackpad - I love the larger trackpad, so much more intuitive and useful than the standard PC trackpads. I have noticed this style is catching on in other PC brands (thanks Apple).

Solid State Drive - One of the main reasons I chose the Samsung Chromebook over the Acer Chromebook, other than aesthetics, was the SSD. Although only 16GB, with Google Drive's 100GB cloud storage, I have plenty of room for my files and pictures. When I am using the Chromebook, several tabs open and typing away, I am still surprised how the machine makes NO noise. The casing never gets hot, I have noticed it becomes warm while in use, but that is to be expected and is not a distraction. The fast and soundless SSD leads me to my following point . . .

Battery Life - This is the best feature of the Chromebook. I have clocked in over 6 hours of battery life before charging. I have yet to run the battery down lower than 25% because I never need to! The simplicity of the operating system (Chrome OS) and the fact that the traditional hard drive with moving parts has been replaced by a flash drive absolutely contributes to the Chromebook's lasting battery life. Of course, when I am on batter power, I turn the brightness down. I no longer even bother bringing the power cord with me to school since I can get plenty of work done between charges.

Things I'm Getting Used To . . .

I was an early adopter to the Chrome web browser because it was always the fastest on the operating systems I used. With that said, I would consider myself very familiar with how to use the Chrome features. However, using Chrome OS was an adjustment for me, because it was different than what I was used to. Not worse or harder, just different. I had to get used to using Google Drive instead of Dropbox and using Google Docs instead of LibreOffice or MS Word. Also, I still have my other laptop that I needed to figure out how to sync with my new Chromebook to make switching between machines seamless. After a few days, I was able to figure out a system that worked for me.

Also, the Chromebook doesn't give you a lot of control over how your desktop looks. Yes you can change the background image and arrange the apps however you like, you can even choose to have the dock disappear. Other than that, very little is left to the user to configure. I believe this is intentional to make using the Chromebook the easiest experience for the majority of users.

Although it has not been an issue yet, I would like to mention that I wish that the memory was 4GB instead of 2GG mostly for longevity reasons. I will have to update this review if that becomes an apparent issue in the future.

To summarize, I love the Chromebook and it certainly makes a very good laptop replacement, for now. It works great for my needs and since I am always around wi-fi. Also, this laptop is beautiful. Looks aren't everything, but beautiful things sure are inspiring.

I'm not going to go into great detail about the Samsung 11.6" Chromebook in this review.  I've read many of the reviews and I can say that there are others that have covered this is great detail already.  But I'll throw in my viewpoint on a few items.  First, as most have indicated - This isn't a Windows PC, so if that is what you are looking to purchase (or replace), then most likely you'll find a few critical elements missing (oh, such as being able to install Windows Software) that will be a deal breaker.  It is absolutely critical that purchasers of this device understand what it is and what it isn't.

So what is it?  I like to call it a Web Appliance, because that's where it excels.  It's a small computer with keyboard that gets you access to the Internet & Cloud based computing.  So can you only use it for Web browsing?  No, it can be much more than that if you are willing to move away from the Windows PC paradigm of computing and consider Apps, in particular Google Apps/Docs to do your work.  If you are, then this little machine can cover (almost all) web browsing needs, (light) word processing, presentation and spreadsheet work.  But you'll be using Google Docs for that effort which isn't MS Office, but for most work is sufficient.

Another sweet spot for me is the simple fact that I have had it with Windows PC, as powerful and capable as they can be, they are optimal for about 6 months.. then the SW hogs takeover and within a year or two your machine is dreadfully slow and needs a full re-format and reinstall of Windows.  Then the cycle starts over.  BTW, I'm a PC guy - I've only ever had MS Windows PC and still figure I need at least one functioning Windows PC in the house.  I use Adobe products (Lightroom / Photoshop) and to do that I still need a full functioning Mac or PC.  So devices like the Chromebook don't fully replace those, but sure simplify keeping a family of 6 up and running with basic computing needs and internet access.  And moving to Cloud computing and document storage simplify data access and backup.

Negatives:  I'm not concerned about things the chromebook never claimed to do.  But there are some features  that Chromebooks claim to do that they either don't do or don't do well.  First - Printing.  There is no easy way to print to (most) existing home printers.  You can set it up to use Google Cloud print - it does work, but not without it's share of  hassles.  I do use it that way, but then I have to go to my full featured PC and log into my Google Account.  Then it works seamlessly.  But if your PC is in sleep mode or off, no go.  The print job is queued.  (The exception to this is if you have a true cloud enabled printer, then you can print directly.  But for most of us that means buying a new printer as our existing printers won't have that capability.)  SECOND:  Streaming, such as Netflix.  On the particular Chromebook device I purchased, Netflix is not supported.  This seems to be a big miss by Google.  They are working on it and I'm guessing it will get there, but Streaming is the future of media delivery and Chromebooks need to support it as much as possible.  Streaming is a Cloud feature, right?  THIRD:  Keyboard/Mouse - Awesome keyboard physically, but there is a bit of a learning curve on a few items if you've only ever used MAC/PC solutions.  But I'll give Google/Chrome credit - if people learn how to use both the onscreen keyboard help or the online help system, help is very much available.  You just have to be a bit patient to learn the system.

Google realized something most of us don't quite realize yet:  hardware is a commodity, and while it is still following Moore's Law with respect to overall horsepower/capability, for what most people do with their laptops/netbooks/tablets, they don't actually need a 1000-2000 laptop.

I will add that in my personal computing wardrobe, I have a work issued Dell Latitude laptop, an iPhone 4S, a Dell Zino, an iPad 3, a Kindle Paperwhite and now a Chromebook.

Here's the thing.  For work, I need a windows laptop for now for the reason most people do:  working with images, using Microsoft office, transferring and managing files, working on the VPN and collaborating with my customers and coworkers.

But when my work laptop is off, there are basically 5 things I always do:  1) read books, 2) occasionally let the kids play games, 3) consume media, 4) surf the web and 5) email/communicate with others.

Despite the assortment of devices I have, the ones I use the most are the Kindle and my iPhone.  The iPad is neat, but usually I find myself starting a task which is just easier with a keyboard.  It's become a toy for the kids and for my wife to use for Pinterest/Facebook.

I really hated the idea of turning my work laptop back on at night, and I really felt like the iPad didn't enable me to do enough with it that I started looking at buying a second laptop.

I couldn't find a laptop that was of decent quality, weighing less than 4 lbs with a SSD running an ARM CPU that offers at least 4 hours of battery life.  This meant either buying a very heavy and very cheap laptop which was prone to failure for $350-$450, or spending between $800-$1000 for a MBA or Windows 8 ultrabook.

I took a gamble and purchased the Chromebook, and based on many of the mixed reviews, didn't know if I would be happy with the purchase or not.

Let me get the negatives out of the way first, because there are a few:

1.  As others have pointed, the body is not unibody aluminum.  It creaks and is plastic, so you'll get some moaning and groaning if you hold it a certain way, and it will probably have its paint peel over time.
2.  The keyboard sounds like it needs to be oiled.  Never used a squeaky keyboard before, but whatever.
3.  The ports are all in the back.  Can be annoying if you need to use them, especially USB.
4.  If you are not looking at the display head on, it will wash out and be unviewable.  45 degrees or more from dead on center and good luck seeing what is on screen.
5.  I would often zone out and forget I'm not using a laptop.  Since I don't use Google Docs, I would have to lug out my PC to edit a document.
6.  This is minor, and may be user error as I learn to use the Chromebook, but since it doesn't run apps per-se, there aren't any alerts or notifications you can set up.  Example - on my work laptop I installed Google Talk, so I always get a pop-up notification in the system tray when new email arrives.  Not so on Chromebook.
7.  The webcam is not good at all.

If those are dealbreakers for you, you probably shouldn't be buying a Chromebook.

Now for what it does well:

1.  Price.  It's $249.  You get 2 years of 100 GB Google Drive storage, and 10 go-go in flight internet passes.  If you are someone like me who (up until now) pays Google for storage space (or someone else like Dropbox, box.net, etc), that's $120 you will save over 2 years versus getting a monthly plan.  The internet is also worth to me $10 a pass.  If you're a Google user and fly a decent amount, this is almost a no-cost purchase.

2.  Even if you're not, I dare someone to find an ARM based netbook weighing less than 3 lbs that gets more than 5 hours of battery life with a great keyboard for less than $400.

3.  Chrome runs fine for just about anything that is not CPU intensive, but again, if you need that level of horsepower, you either already have a Macbook Air/Pro or a heavy duty Wintel laptop.  For surfing the web, watching amazon prime, communicating with friends, viewing images, reading news and consuming information, writing your blog, streaming music, this is plenty sufficient.

4.  The keyboard is phenomenal.  It does sound squeaky, but it's extremely comfortable to type on.

5.  The trackpad (and maybe I have low expectations) works great as well.  No jumping around, getting lost on the screen, great responsiveness.  Beats anything I've used on windows laptops.

6.  It's an attractive piece of hardware.  Derivative?  Yep.  But who cares.  It looks good.  People keep asking me what it is when I'm at Starbucks with it powered up.

7.  It closes the gap for me between my smartphone and my work PC.  Would it be nice if it had a touchscreen and ran Android apps?  Sure.  But at $249, I can now justify buying the next Chromebook, as I assume at some point they will have touchscreens and run apps.  I usually have my phone nearby, so if I need to play games, run apps, or call someone I have it.

8.  This is a negative of all tablets, but they're extremely difficult to use if they aren't sitting on your lap.  Reading books on a tablet is not fun right now, the tablet is too heavy.  The Chromebook is perfect for most environments - it rests on your lap or can sit on a table.

Bottom line, this is a great device for what it is.  If you find yourself wishing your tablet had a keyboard, or if you find yourself using your tablet for nothing but games and email, then you probably will find this to be great.  If you worry about having access to Microsoft Office, or needing something which will let you print, or you find yourself often in places with no internet, you probably should consider other options.

When I'm sitting around watching TV, or in a coffee establishment/restaurant, at the airport, or parked at work, I reach for my Chromebook most of the time.  If not, then I probably either need my work laptop or my phone.

And since they're so cheap, I don't worry about buying the next one whenever it comes out.

First off, let's just get this out of the way.  If you come to a Chromebook expecting a machine to run the latest games on or with expectations that it will do the same things as a $500 Windows laptop, you've come to the wrong place.

That said, if what you are looking for is a reasonably well-built lightweight machine that provides solid basic applications at a low cost, this is a great choice.  Yes, it's just a machine that runs "just a web browser."  But if you let that limit your view of what's possible, you're missing out.

Even inside Google's ecosystem lies enough power to provide most of your needs.  A good solid word processor, a spreadsheet, a usable "forms" application for basic databases, and even a presentation graphics package.  Throw in Google Mail and Picasa, and what else does a novice computer user need?  Facebook, YouTube, and even some of the video services (although, because of its reliance on Microsoft Silverlight, sadly not Netflix) all run beautifully.  It also does a fine job of playing local media stored on a thumb drive or even a small hard drive.

Even advanced users will find something to like about this Chromebook.  It's super lightweight, all solid state, and the 6-hour battery life is perfect for a "second laptop" around the house or for the long excursions where carrying a full-function laptop is too much weight.  Samsung's build quality is fantastic, especially for such a low-cost product. I'm a systems administrator, and it makes a perfect go-anywhere SSH and RDP terminal at a low-cost and light weight.

Chrome's "offline mode" does a superb job of letting you use Google Drive's features without needing a full-time net connection, so much of what makes this a usable machine doesn't need a tether to the network to work.  As more and more applications are developed to support "offlining" (which is not just limited to Chromebooks) this will only improve.

No, it's not a replacement (yet) for a full-function computer for everybody.  It is a great starter machine for a novice user, or a second machine for a more advanced user that's willing to accept that World of Warcraft isn't happening on this machine.

There is a lot to talk about in relation to the Chromebook, and I think many people have done a fantastic job of reviewing what they love and don't love about the Chromebook. I will skip a lot of that - yes it's sleek, the keyboard is great and the screen is reasonable for personal use, but I wanted to share some of the things that currently do, and potentially would make this an ideal laptop for a lot of people. These are some minor things and some major things, in no particular order.

For Chromebook information, compatible accessories and tutorials on installing Linux, head over to: whatthetech.info/samsungchromebook

----------------------------
Now you may be surprised (even horrified) to know that I sold my Macbook (5,1 - aluminum) to buy the Chromebook. Of course, I made a nice profit after trading in a $500 used laptop for a $250 new one, but many would consider this a huge downgrade. I did so for several reasons.

1) I'm quite heavily invested in Google's ecosystem. I use Gmail, Google Docs, Google Calendars and almost every other app they offer in my day-to-day life. No I don't like their privacy policies, but the services they offer (for free I might add) are just amazing! The Google Drive free 100GB offer was also a huge draw, as I had just run out of dropbox space, and really don't feel like paying money for "storage" that I would only use part of.

2) I realized that about 95% of the work I do is web-based. Seriously. I am a photographer by trade, and so I can never be entirely without a real computer, but apart from that all I do is blog, write articles, review products and browse the web. Having a hackintosh desktop means I can (and do) run any OS, and I can always do my real work there. I rarely (and I mean almost never) have to do work away from home, so this was not really an issue. Also I would say 95% of the places I hang out (home, cafs, friend's places, even my church) have high-speed wi-fi. Being cloud-based, Google's OS is very limited without wifi. The good news is, there is support for playing media, managing files and certain apps offline, so if I don't have wi-fi or am not willing to pay for it (airports), it's not dead!

3) The macbook was just not a great laptop to run Linux from. I tried multiple things, but for some reason it was just a pain. Support for the network card was spotty at best, the bluetooth would lag my mouse, the trackpad was difficult to work with. I just wasn't impressed. Now while there is no official support for Linux on the Chromebook, but some clever folks have already created a version of Ubuntu that can be run directly from an SD card (tutorial at the aforementioned link). I have two reasons for wanting to run linux; the first is to be able to use the Tor browser safely. The second is to have a safe environment in which to learn some Unix (yes I know OSX is based on it, but it's different). The chromebook is ideal for this because you can return to factory settings without too much hassle, and with much of your data being cloud-based, you simply sign in to a new installation and wait for a few small apps to download!

Now there are a few limiting factors to the functionality. Here are some things I would like to see change/happen with the Chromebook and ChromeOS:

1) Widgets. I'm going to start with the most controversial one, and that is the ability to run widgets. Now I'm not talking about some monstrous hardware monitoring widget that spans half the 11 screen (although I would be interested to see a few stats), but I wouldn't say no to a clock, Gmail monitor and perhaps a few other little helpful apps. In Ubuntu I have a few nice "applets" that don't take up much screen real estate or resources, but allow me to tweet, check the weather and get email previews without opening an app (per se, yes I know the apps are running in the background but you know what I mean!)

2) The ability to rearrange the app launcher. Despite being able to reorder apps in the launchbar, it is not possible to rearrange apps in the app launcher window. They are arranged by date downloaded by default, however this leaves the stock apps at the top of the list/on the first page. At least the app launcher will open on the page last scrolled to (unless you restart), so I don't always have to scroll around for my most-used apps, but not being able to put my most-used apps first is a minor annoyance bordering on a real issue. *UPDATE* David left a comment on this review letting me know that this feature has been added to the dev channel for future release - this is great news!

3) Simple scrolling with a mouse. I have been using laptops for about 15 years now, and I've never quite gotten used to only using a trackpad, so I like to travel with an Apple Mighty Mouse in my bag at all times. That said, when I hooked up my mouse (which was a very easy process), I noticed that despite being turned on, simple scrolling wasn't working. I tried a second mouse to be sure, and the issue was replicated, so I'm filing this as a bug and hoping Google can get a fix out. Aside from this minor issue I have found using a mouse (and the trackpad) to be a very nice experience!). *UPDATE* See bottom of review!

4) Better page caching. Perhaps in an effort to save space from being used by the cache, if you leave a tab unclicked on for a short amount of time, you will have to reload it when you click on it again. Now granted, this is only a two-three second delay in accessing my information, but if you happen to be somewhere with a slow internet connection this can be a real pain. I am very glad for services such as "Read Later Fast" which allows you to save a webpage to read at your leisure (also this works in offline mode), but on the go the reloading of pages can be a little annoying. I have noticed that this doesn't happen all the time, and it doesn't happen with every web page. If anyone could offer some insight, I would be much obliged!

5) More control in the file manager. When accessing the built-in file manager, you are immediately greeted with two sidebar folders: Google Drive and Downloads. Now I am very glad for my free 100GB storage, as well as the option to make files available while offline, however as someone who is particular about their file management system, the inability to place folders on the sidebar for easy access is a little frustrating. All I want is to be able to make an audiobook folder, an images folder and a folder for current word documents, and have them be quickly accessed...nothing too much to ask?

6) Charging port. For goodness sake, this is about the worst design I have seen on a charger to date. Not only is the charging jack fragile, but it goes deep enough inside the laptop that a knock is going to bend it or worse! At first I thought that Apple had sole rights to chargers that maintained connection through magnetism, but it seems that Microsoft also successfully patented a similar design for their surface tablets, so I don't think it's outside the realms of possibility? Nothing has happened yet, but I keep having to look over at my excitable dog...just in case... :)

OVERALL
A portable, well-performing laptop who's limitations are easily fixed in future generations. I like ChromeOS, but I LOVE running Chrubuntu Linux on the device. I can easily use it for watching videos, listening to audiobooks and music, as well as blogging and word processing. The battery life is good, the screen is decent, and having USB 3.0 and HDMI are a real boon. I definitely recommend you give this a try - it's a cheap way to get a decent laptop, and you might just fall in love.

Despite the pitfalls, the price and performance left me feeling that four stars would be just too harsh. I really do enjoy my Chromebook, both under ChromeOS and Chrubuntu, and on the plus side my wife no longer wants a more expensive macbook - she'll be getting a Chromebook soon!

I bought a pricier version of the Chromebook (Series 5 550) back in August 2012 after getting fed up with my Vaio laptop's slow boot speed and constant need to update software, both OS and AV related, all of which impeded my simple desire to be able to check email, browse a few websites for a couple minutes, and then log-off. The Chromebook satisfied all of my desires for a super-fast functional netbook so well that when my parents' desktop PC broke down, I knew precisely what to buy them for my father's 60th - this newer Chromebook.

After setting it up for them - a doddle really, enter the password for your wireless connection and ensure you have a Google account and that's it - I showed them how easy it was to use. Simply open or close the Chromebook's lid to turn it on and off. Boot speed is literally seconds. Updates are necessary though these are few and far between and also take literally seconds to update. And browsing is completely straightforward - Chrome looks simpler as a browser than IE.

Comparing my Chromebook and this newer Chromebook, there are some differences that are noticeable. On the newer model, the power cable plugs into the back, which is also where the USB slots are, while the 550 plugs onto the left hand side where the USB slots are also housed. Battery life on my 550 is a couple hours longer, the screen is larger, and it looks sleeker - the newer model folds up leaving a kind of line at the back making it look a bit clunky, design wise. Then again my 550 is also pricier (though with the cash-back offer Samsung ran when I bought it at PC World, the difference was only fifty pounds).

But in terms of speed and browsing, there's no noticeable difference. My parents are delighted with the Chromebook and love the speed and ease with which they can go online, check email, and then turn it off all within a minute whereas their old desktop clunker took about 15 minutes to fully start up and, when it did, browsing the internet was a slow and joyless activity (my father's words).

The speed of Chromebook's boot up time is because the OS is in the Cloud (internet storage) so without an internet connection, this device is more or less worthless - this is why I've kept my Vaio for Office, movies, and downloads. It also doesn't have a disc drive so you can't play DVDs or Blu-Rays on it, and you can't download on to it, so no iTunes, or anything that requires downloading - the plus side being you don't need anti-virus software as no viruses can download onto your machine.

For those looking for an affordable and easy to use device but don't like tablets and prefer using a mouse and keyboard (a lot more people than you think) then Chromebook is for me, and now my parents, the only way to go.

I'm on week one with my new Chromebook, which I actually bought from Best Buy. I would have bought it on Amazon but they were out, and I needed something as soon as possible. I had done quite a bit of research on this laptop, debating between getting this and the Chromebox, but eventually decided on this because it was cheaper and more portable. Anyhow, I will update this review as time goes on, but I wanted to post my initial impressions for anyone who is on the fence about purchasing this item over a similar low-end E-machines or Acer laptop.

First impressions: It's smaller than I thought it would be, but I'm okay with it. It's still bigger than the tablet I have, which measures in at 10.1 inches. If you have bad eyes or like a bigger screen on your laptop, this probably isn't for you, unless you're planning on hooking up the HDMI out to an external monitor. The desktop environment looks remarkably similar to a Windows PC. The icons you will use most are in the lower left hand corner, where you would normally find the start bar. This laptop is fast and responsive. I generally keep up about 8-10 tabs on my browser, and this thing has no problem handling that. It really does boot up in 10 seconds (and in my experience, less than that). No waiting through windows boot screens, no antivirus updates to manage.

I love the keyboard. It's a chiclet style keyboard, similar to what you'd see on a Mac air, but it is very fun to type on. The touchpad is pretty big, which is good, and you can either tap or click to select things. I'm not super impressed with the responsiveness of the trackpad, but I'll reserve judgement until I've messed around with the sensitivity settings a little.

The lower right hand has the date and time, as well as a battery meter. Clicking on it gets you to the settings and allows you to see how much time the laptop thinks you'll get out of the battery. Fun fact: when you plug the laptop in, that timer changes to show you how much longer it will take before it's charged. While we're on the topic of battery life, I haven't really gotten a chance to put the computer through it's paces, but I have been taking it to class with me on Thursdays, where I'm in class from 11:30am-10pm, and I use it for a couple hours at a time, several times throughout the day. I left it sitting, off, in my backpack until Friday night when I got home from work (about 9pm) and just for funsies I flipped it on to see how dead the battery was, and to my surprise, there was still juice in it. I was pretty impressed, especially because some of the other laptops I've bought in the past really suck down the battery, even while on standy. I'll post more as I get more time in with it.

I'm pretty deeply entrenched in the Google ecosystem, so I was already familiar with alot of the products; Docs, Spreadsheets, Music, Chrome, etc. I love all of them. They run great, and I can still take notes in class in offline mode if there isn't wifi available (which is almost never). Google Docs is just as good as Microsoft word, and lets you do cloud printing. What's not to love?

Overall: I love it. The screen looks better than I expected (especially from a $250 laptop) and the boot time is a thing of beauty. I would definitely recommend this to anyone thinking about getting a cheap computer. This is the perfect laptop for someone who really only does browser-based computing. If you're not sure if that's you, think about what you actually do on the computer. How often do you run a CD with software on it? Are there any specific programs you need to be able to run (like Photoshop or music editing software)? If not, and you're like me, then all you probably do is email, Facebook, Google searches, stream music, and do some word processing, all of which you can do on this laptop.

I was recently thinking about replacing my trusty old MacBook with something a bit lighter. The MacBook has been a workhorse, but at six pounds, I find myself leaving it at home if I'm going any further than the local coffee shop. I toyed with the idea of getting a MacBook Air, which seems like the perfect laptop for me, but coming off a long stretch of unemployment, the price was too steep for my meager budget. Then the Samsung Chromebook came out.

I do all my writing in Google Docs, so the Chromebook seemed like it might be the perfect laptop for my needs. It is light (2.31 pounds), it has a good keyboard, and it is specifically designed to work well with Google stuff. Best of all, it was only $249--about a third of the price of a MacBook Air. What could possibly go wrong?

Not much, as it turns out. After using the laptop for a few weeks now, I can report that it lives up to its billing. For anyone who has replaced their Microsoft Office with Google's Docs, the Chromebook it certainly worth considering. That's not to say it is perfect. There are some problems with the Chromebook. Some of these problems are minor, but some are not. I'll get to the problems in a minute, but first, here's a quick rundown of the computers fine points.

Unlike almost every laptop on the planet, the Chromebook runs neither Windows nor OSX. It has its own operating system, which is entirely based around Google's Chrome browser. Any documents you create are saved in the Google Drive window. Sometimes this can be  a little disorienting. If you go to change the Settings on the computer, for instance, it opens as a window in Chrome.

You have option of installing additional programs, but only those that are available through the Chrome store. In this respect, it's a bit like an iPad, but with real keyboard. Fortunately, the Chrome Store is very robust at this point. I needed a flowchart program, for instance, and I was able to find one that fit my needs perfectly (Lucidcharts) without any difficulty. However, if your business relies on a specific software package, the Chromebook might not suit your needs. The Chrome Store is worth checking though as many major cloud-based systems (such as Salesforce) offer Chrome apps.

The keyboard is good on the Chromebook. It is a chiclet-style keyboard nearly identical to the one on the MacBook Air in appearance and feel. The one odd characteristic of the keyboard is the replacement of the Caps Lock key with a key that brings up the applications menu; a bit like the Windows key on a PC. Fortunately, you can easily switch this key back to a Caps Lock function in the Settings menu. I suspect that most people will want to do this right away.

The computer does not include many ports, but the ones it has are good ones. They include an HDMI port for hooking the computer up to a high-def TV, a USB 2 and a USB 3 port. It has an SD card slot that will accept SD, SDHC and SDXC cards, and it has a USIM slot, which, if I can figure out how to use it (and it isn't too expensive to use), might be useful for using the Chromebook at my favorite local coffee shop, which doesn't have WiFi.

Of course, the biggest thing the computer has going for it is its weight. At less than two-and-a-half pounds, I found myself checking my briefcase after leaving the house to make sure I had remembered to bring it. After four years of lugging around my old MacBook it was a nice change.

One of the features that helped me decide to purchase the Chromebook was the inclusion of multiple finger gestures. Like the MacBook, you can scroll down by dragging down the trackpad with two fingers. Tap to click is available for those of you who like this feature, although personally, it's the first thing I turn off. Like the PC, it offers a right and left click, which is one of the few things I have always preferred about PCs. Since there are no right and left buttons on the Chromebook, the right click is accessed by clicking with two fingers.

Of course, it's not all goodness and light. There are some things you should consider before buying the Chromebook. People who rely on the Macbook's lighted keyboard are going to be disappointed to find that this feature is missing. It also requires you to have a Google account and work, at least part of the time, on line. The computer has a sync feature that lets you continue working when you are not online, but it is really intended as more of a stopgap than an alternative. The system prefers to be connected.

When it is shipped, there is a styrofoam sheet that separates the keyboard from the screen. You might want to save this sheet. After carrying the laptop around for a few days, I noticed a gray smudge on the screen where it came in contact with the bottom of the keyboard. This wiped off easily, still, you might want to use that styrofoam sheet to skip this necessity.

If you are using multiple tabs in Chrome, the system essentially turns off the tabs that you are not using. This means there is sometimes a slight lag as the page is redisplayed when you click from tab to tab. How much of a lag seems to depend more on your wireless connection than on the computer.

The biggest drawback for the Chromebook is its inability to handle special characters easily. By special characters, I don't simply mean things like vowels with accent marks (, , , , ), but even the everyday em dash--like the one I just used. Here is one area where the Mac has outshone all other operating systems since the beginning. You want to type an em dash? Hold down the Option and shift keys and press the hyphen key. Voila! you have an em dash. To do the same thing on a PC requires a little more work. You have to hold down the alt key and press 0151 on the numeric keypad (it won't work on the number keys). That's a bit more work, and it's a real pain in the ass on a PC laptop, where to access the numeric keypad, you have to press a function key to turn part of your keyboard into a keypad temporarily.

But that is nothing compared to the Chromebook where to enter an em dash, you have hold down Control and Shift Keys and press U, then type 2014, and then hit enter. Essentially seven key gestures for one character. To make matters worse, this command sequence doesn't work in the actual Google documents. there are ways around this, but none of them are very good. You can choose special characters from the insert menu, which is probably the easiest way, or you can assign certain key combinations to convert to other characters. You could, for instance, assign a double dash to turn into an em dash (Microsoft Word does this), but this will only work if the dashes are set off from the other words by a space. The same for other special characters, which makes this feature a lot less useful.

In spite of these problems, the Chromebook is a nearly perfect laptop for a specific market segment. If you are someone who is working primarily (or better yet, exclusively) in Google Docs, this is the laptop for you. I recommend the Chromebook wholeheartedly. It is a great little machine at an astounding price.

I'm a professional writer working on my twelfth novel.  The dream of a second computer as portable as a pad of paper was just too tempting, and I ordered the Samsung Chromebook after Christmas.  Demand is high.  There was a brief delay in delivery.  But the Chromebook arrived on a Thursday, and as promised, it proved to be a very eager machine.

The set up was simple and quick.  Google had me synched and flying in minutes.  The screen seemed dim, but I expected that from the reviews.  The keyboard had a good feel.  The touch pad was better than most.  (There wasn't a lot of cursing time.)  But my wireless mouse was slow and sloppy.  So I bought a bluetooth mouse and found the same problem, which meant another trip to the store to get my money back.  A little wired mouse proved good enough, and over the weekend I began settling into my new life as a roving, coffee-infused author.

I've been working more and more with Google Docs.  My old laptop has no major problems handling novel-length files, and while there are quirks and kinks with Docs, I love the idea of backing up my ideas while avoiding Microsoft Word.  But the Chromebook wasn't thrilled with files of 80 and 90 thousand words.  Loading was slow.  Navigation was very slow.  Also bothersome was how the cursor didn't quite line up with the words, always hanging a little below.  And worse, that sweet keyboard let me type quickly--too quickly, since the text on the screen was always a couple seconds behind.

This wasn't going to end the experiment, but I was seeing troubles with my data.

Reviewers love to talk about the "ecosystems" of various tech giant.  I like some of Google's options.  Google Play, for instance.  But when it comes to apps, and with movies that can be bought...well, Google doesn't have an ecosystem so much as a weed patch.

Again, none of this was causing me soul-searing grief.  It was just bothersome.

But then on Sunday night--again, my Chromebook arrived on Thursday--the touch pad quit working.  The tiny plug-in mouse still functioned, but not the touch pad.  I turned off the Chromebook and rebooted.  I did that twice.  (The machine is wonderfully quick, coming back from the dead.)  But the pad remained comatose.  A quick googling for help, and I instantly learned that I wasn't the only customer who had discovered this tendency.

I decided to return the machine, printing out the Amazon labels while I started hunting for a replacement.  I ordered one of the last ultrabooks running with Windows 7.  More money by a lot, but that's a short term expense.  $249 dollars is a lot of cash if the toy breaks in four days, or even in a year and four days.

Obviously these problems will be solved someday, what with updated software and design changes.  But my book is due in April, and I can't wait.

A final note:  The next morning, I turned on the Chromebook to wipe it back to its factory settings.  And the touch pad was working again.

Google is a mysterious deity.

Wonderful laptop!!! I have managed to replace my Windows 7 work laptop with this tiny machine. Only face several hurdles in the workplace as follows:

This a great alternate laptop great for taking out and seems to fit bill for something more than tablet and less than a real laptop and as long as you have some other computer somewhere this is fine

Excellent product for the price. Light, sleak, fast, hassle-free -------. Google has again lived up to its reputation. I guess the only changes it could make for a few more bucks are: (1) Louder audio speakers, (2) better display.
We returned it because it took at least a minute or longer to load sites.  Our IPad worked on the same server and it would load in five or less seconds.
I highly recommend it for most people, at least as a 2nd computer.  Maybe even a 2nd and 3rd computer.  Thinking of buying another, as my wife has been using it more and more.

I had this Chromebook for 8 days.  There was lots to like, but it seems to be very picky about what periperhals it will recognize in the USB ports.  The small Kensington mouse that I like to use wasn't recognized by it.  At first, I wondered if it was me, but then I tried the same mouse in my husband's Acer Chromebook, and all 4 of its USB ports recognized it immediately.

I thought maybe it was just my Samsung Chromebook, so I took it back to Best Buy.  The mouse they put in  at the Geek Squad worked.  I figured it was just the Kensington mouse that it was picky about so I bought another one at Best Buy and tried it out in the store: no go.  The Google Chrome Sales Specialist was called over.  She used the mouse I had just bought on her personal Samsung Chromebook, which was not the  Exynos 5 Dual Processor Samsung, but a different model. It worked immediately.  Then we went to the  Exynos 5 Dual Processor Samsung in the store that was the display model, and it wouldn't recognize it.

Obviously, the problem isn't in all Samsung Chromebooks, but does seem to be an issue with the new one, the $249 one.

I didn't want something so picky, so I exchanged it for the Acer Chromebook.

I guess  differences between the Acer and the Samsung include the Samsung looks cooler, weighs less, has longer battery life, and doesn't have an regular Intel processor so it is very quiet.  However, it seems very picky in terms of peripherals, doesn't play Netflix yet, and doesn't have a replaceable battery.  Also, the Acer doesn't have Bluetooth capability, and the Samsung does.

I decided to go with the Acer.  I wanted to love the Samsung but the USB issue and the no Netflix makes a difference, though the Netflix issue is something they are working on.
A good little notebook for the price.  Had been looking for a small laptop for downstairs, and this one is perfect.
Purchased this for my husband and he is very happy with the performance and the size.  Easy to take with us on our trips
The misleading advertising on the Chromebook led me to believe that Netflix would work. I does not. Buy a laptop.
This chromebook is very light ,my daughter in college she loves it ,so is my husband i bought him one for christmas,this is lighter than  ipad,and work just like a laptop.

I had waited a few weeks after purchasing because Amazon was out of stock. The Chrome Book showed up earlier than Amazon had predicted which was nice. It's not a power house laptop but it's great for web surfing, email, youtube, and all of the apps that come with it. I found that I can use Google's Remote Desktop app to connect to my Windows 7 and Ubuntu boxes and use them in full screen mode, basically simulating a Windows or Linux laptop, which is amazing. The keyboard is perfect. The video camera is a little slow in response time. I like how quickly the laptop boots up and comes out of standby. The power seems to last for a while without needing to be recharged. One more of my favorite things is how it's silent (no fans) and doesn't get hot since everything is solid state. I'd highly recommend this to everyone. Thanks!

I purchased this for my husband because basically all he needs from a computer is to browse the internet and type documents.  I  am the one that would solve all the issues with our Windows computers and figured at least I wouldn't have to leave what I was doing every time he had a problem on the PC. Also, I had already decided to switch from Sugarsync to Google Drive to back up all of my files online, mainly because I can watch my home videos directly from the cloud which I couldn't do with Sugarsync. So, the 100 GBs of free storage that comes with Chromebook basically almost cut the price in half for me (a $120 discount considering the current $5 monthly price for that storage). Now, I have found myself using this thing every chance I get when my husband is not.

I have an Android tablet that is great for some things, but I love having a real keyboard for writing and communication. It is really terrific for 95% of our needs, although for now a PC is still necessary for certain software. But personally, I'm fully behind Google Apps as a replacement for Microsoft Office programs. In any case, I don't see why any family needs more than one full OS desktop, be it Mac or Windows, that can be shared by all. Chromebooks are so inexpensive,every family member can have one for personal use.

Bought this for the wife as she was always causing something 'crazy' to go wrong on my Sony Vaio and it was a mistake to give this to her -- I want it! No, seriously! It's fast, sleek and sexy. Can't really comment on the performance specs but it beats the living heck out of what I'm now forced to use. I'm getting one for myself!
Great Christmas Gift for our daughter. We haven't seen her since she got it. Movies, email and lots of enjoyment.

So I've been looking at this Chromebook for a few months now, after someone at work (I work in IT at school) brought one in. I did a lot of research and read a lot of reviews, and finally purchased one after I got some extra spending cash and a credit card. I bought this for school and of course personal use, and it's absolutely perfect--in regards to what I thought it would be and what it can do.

First off, disregard reviews from customers who are unsatisfied with the limitations of the Chromebook. If you didn't know it couldn't do something you desired, it's on your part; you should have done research into what exactly a Chromebook can and can't do.

So yes, it's essentially a quick and simple computer that goes online. I'll be using this for writing papers, and doing all online related work for school. Quick shotgun of my personal assessment: very fast boot-up time as expected, keyboard is fantastic (very Mac-esque, one of the few things I like about macbooks), battery time is great, display is great (really), haven't tested the camera yet, trackpad could be better (at times, it's a bit off but not a big deal and it's working fine now), sound is great, build quality is great.

Anyway, feel free to shoot any questions you may have about the Chromebook. I love Google and all, but I'm not biased enough to disregard the truth of any flaws.

Edit - Random miscellaneous things: headphone needs to be pushed in very firmly into the jack, bottom of laptop gets warm/hot but definitely nowhere as hot as a normal laptop with a standard processor.
Very light, quiet, and cool.  Great for taking on the go.  Tough getting use to from using typical laptop.  Con:  cannot download certain things like Itunes.

Pros:

This baby laptop has some great features.
It's super light.
The battery life is crazy long.
It surfs and sends email like a dream.
I love the touchpad--so intuitive and responsive.
It's generally great for anything online.
It plays online videos very smoothly.
Google chat video is great too.

Cons:
On the downside, offline uses aren't good at all.
It can't print to a regular networked printer unless its some special printer with an eprint feature--a major drawback IMO.
The music file system can't deal with music on your hard drive--it wants to upload everything to the cloud. If you have lots of music files that exceed 100G, then you'll have to pick and choose. The music service also can't manage wav files. Really, no wavs?
It isn't compatible with MS Office, so no word, powerpoint, or excel. Of course, google has versions of all of these programs, but they're markedle inferior to the MS stuff. And let's face it, for work applications MS is the standard and the google apps are some weird freebie sub-standard.

Bottom line:
Buy this for surfing, but don't expect it to replace a full-fledged laptop.

My husband purchased the Samsung Chromebook for me for Christmas. I don't consider myself any more tech-savvy than the average thirty something- maybe even less (which you will quickly find out as you read). If it's electronic and user friendly and I can figure it out in a few clicks, I'm happy. Basically, you won't find me digging through YouTube tutorials to figure out my technical problems. Many people are comparing this machine to a MacBook. And I would agree that it looks and feels like one. Otherwise this is nothing like a Macbook, because it's barely a computer in my opinion. It's an over sized smartphone with a keyboard.  Nothing is saved onto it: everything you download, create in google drive, edit in photo editor apps-goes directly into the google cloud. I personally don't know that I was ready for this. Maybe I need to be since that is where we are headed. But If I knew this before I opened it, I would have probably returned it. And this is why:

The first thing I don't like about this, is that you can't download any software directly onto the machine. I can't put a photo editing program like Lightbox onto this machine. You can only use the crappy photo editor apps online.

Secondly, Netflix doesn't work on this machine.. WTH!! What a major mistake on Google's part to release it without compatibility with Netflix. I don't know how many people are like me, but I don't pay $120/mo for cable. I pay $8/mo for Netflix. This is what I watch nightly; I am so pissy that I can't use my new device to watch Louie..sometimes I get so annoyed I am tempted to quick list this thing on Ebay.

Thirdly, the apps don't open in the slick ipad way, they open in a browser window which doesn't seem like a huge deal, but I think it's pretty lame and an aesthetic faux pas.

Overall, I would not highly recommend this machine for anything other than perusing the internet and playing games. Maybe it has more abilities, but my limited tech intelligence and motivation leads me to believe it doesn't.

I was able to upload my iTunes library to google music and move everything else over to google drive. So let me break down my experience so far.

Everything worked perfectly out of the box. The keyboard is truly a dream to work on. I am able to open .zip and .rar files natively and there are extensions or web apps that replace everything I did on my macbook pro. I wanted to share my experience with this little device with Amazon user. First I checked the device in Best Buy and it seemed very much like a apple macbook air without the $1000+ price tag. It is web based device and if you do off line computing spreadsheets etc, this is not a device for you. Anyways I decided to buy one and give try. The first unit I bought was keep crashing or screening getting frozen and all kinds of issues. I was very disappointed and keep sending google a report indicating that Chrome OS sucks. But shortly after I decided to give a try to second device and see how that goes. Well I got the second unit and so far zero problems. It works perfectly and I am very happy with it. If you are experiencing issues with the device such as sw crashes or screen locking up on you, don't waste your time because the issue is the hardware and replace the unit ASAP.

Exactly what we expected.  Great size, light weight, enables daughter to access web sites and applications used by her teachers.  She is allowed to use it in the classroom for note taking, completing homework.  Same operating system as her phone for continuity of user interfaces.  $249, no tax, no shipping.  We did not get it in time for Christmas, but Amazon alerted me to the fact that the item would not arrive by the holiday.  She got a picture of the item in her stocking and she was thrilled.

There's a lot to like about this unit. PROS: It's lightweight. Setup (from opening the box to getting online) is minutes (at most). The screen is beautiful. Once set up (with your Chrome account), there are lots of settings and using the unit is simple. The thing is FAST! From power-up to getting online is maybe 20 seconds, except for one thorny issue I have, for which I have already contacted Samsung. Which brings me to the CONS: You MUST (and there's no way around this) sign into your Chrome account EVERY time you boot this machine. This almost prompted me to send it back. The password must be 8 characters, which is even more annoying. If I'm the only user, why do I need to log in and out? Even if you check "Keep Logged In" on your regular Chrome account, you'll have to login every time here. No saving passwords, either. Stupid. Archaic. This alone almost made me send the thing back. After multiple steps, the help menu and poring over the ADVANCED setup (it's not at all like Windows), I was finally able to set my default web page to Google on startup. The Chrome default page requires more clicks to get there every time. Additionally, to place the HOME button in the browser you have to again find the appropriate (and well hidden) settings menu. Once set up (and I hope it never loses its settings), it was fine. The power plug is EXTREMELY small and tight-fitting. I wonder if one good bump on the rear will break it? Time will tell...

In actual use, there's more to like (love): Startup and shutdown is a single-button breeze. Connection to my DSL is fast. You can set up any network and allow automatic connecting (storing your password/WEP key). The keypad is large. A row of dedicated "function" keys above the number keys makes adjustments of volume, brightness and more pretty simple. After charging, the battery shows 6.5 hours of remaining time. This is great for me - if it really lasts that long (time will tell). Opening the lid automatically boots the machine to save even more time. Unlike with Windows, there are no adjustments (that I have found) for screen timeout/dimming, telling the machine what to do when you open/close the lid or hit the power button. It's simple and straightforward - which essentially was what I wanted, though a bit more customizing would be preferable). Inserting an SD card quickly opened a window of its contents. When initially setting up the unit (or going back later), you can use the built-in webcam to snap your picture or load another as a login profile picture. You can set up many Apps within Chrome and download anything you like to the desktop. Font sizes are adjustable and in many ways like within Windows/IE. There is no delete key, only a backspace key. Odd. Menus are somewhat different than within Windows, but as long as things are there, I'll find them, so I have no major complaints about that. All web pages and Apps I tested loaded faster than either of my PCs with XP or Vista (but then anything is faster than those operating systems), but I say this as a comparative: this Samsung unit overall is very fast, opens and scrolls pages quickly, plays YouTube videos very well and though a bit quirky and limited, setting up the browser is simple. Saving web pages (bookmarking) doesn't provide a traditional Favorites List, but maybe I just haven't figured out how to display it? To be fair, I haven't used Chrome until now, and I'm not a huge fan, but it works. I bought this thing for internet only - no Apps. Oh, and the native GMail pops up in a flash. When I called Samsung for support I got to a knowledgeable (English speaking!) guy in minutes, which was refreshing.

Overall, I like it and maybe with a some future software updates, I'll learn to love it. I wold recommend it to anyone looking for a FAST machine that will NOT get viruses (according to Samsung, since there's no OS). If you are afraid of computers but want or need internet and email, this machine is a great choice and is priced right (I paid $249.00 on Amazon).

Quality of this product is good, but it is limited to just the internet and what apps are in the Chrome Google store.  This is not compatiable with most Window programs and the vast majority of software games, apps, programs need Windows to run.  So my kids can't play their favorite games on this Google Chrome product.  My child wants to exchange it for a normal windows lap top or iPad.

This was a perfect purchase for my 9 and 10 year old boys.  They are a great size for them.  I have played on it a bit as well.  With the Chrome OS, it is fast! ......with this Chromebook and have never been unhappy.  I love the fact that I don't always have to be updating it, worrying about spending $$ on security software and Malware protection.  If you can live on the Internet and use "cloud" based software, this is a great way to go at a very inexpensive price.

On paper this thing really stands out, super fast next-gen processor, lightweight Google-oriented operating system, manufactured by a top-shelf company, etc. It's prettymuch the perfect mobile computing device for those who need a full keyboard and basic functionality without the clunkiness of windows.

Software-wise it's dead-simple. Everything runs through the Chrome web browser. This is a little off-putting at first, for example I open the chromebook settings, and I'm in a tab inside the chrome browser. Wtf? So it takes a little getting used to. Also, we had a bit of an experience transferring some MS Office docs to google drive, converting them into Google Docs format, and having a little silliness ensue (spacing, etc got a little wacky). But I can honestly see the software replacing everything I did in Windows.

Hardware-wise this thing is just barely adequate. The reason I say that is because there are areas that really stand out as quality, and others that made me cringe. One of the cringe-worthy items was that the bezel around the LCD screen doesn't tuck neatly into the backing. What this means is that there is a (tiny) edge that pokes out a (tiny) bit all the way around the outside edge of the screen that is a (tiny) bit loose. Like I can stick my fingernail into the seam. The other area that bugged me is the trackpad clicking action feels really cheap, I decided to tap to click instead to avoid using it.

There are those of you who would critique my opinion claiming that I can't expect a $250 laptop to feel 100% premium. I'd answer that by saying it's my right as a consumer to demand unreasonable things. That's how progress is made, and it's why we aren't still using boxy slow laptops from the 90s.

The highlight for me was the form factor, the LCD panel, and the keyboard. The overall shape and design of the chromebook is superb. Light, rigid, and sleek. The screen is large enough for comfortable web browsing, has decent viewing angles, and is very bright on full power. I was also impressed at the clarity and color of the screen. The keyboard as well pays homage to the high-end macbook pro series with it's black chiclet keys and comfortable key presses. It feels premium to me.

I kind of wanted to give this 3/5 stars for the build quality issues mentioned above, but the software is rock solid and the screen/keyboard are great, so I bumped it up to a 4/5 rating.

I'll follow up after some time if anything noteworthy happens.

I am old enough to remember those computer terminals that sat on people's desks and only worked because they were connected by a wire to another remote machine that actually ran the application software. True, it doesn't do everything, and if you only have the luxury of buying one type of computerish gizmo, then this might not be what you want. I purchased the 11-in Samsung Chromebook as a gift when they went on sale for $250. This major price-shift in the chromebook line took it from (IMHO) overpriced, to competitively priced. Because of the new price-point, you can think about this as a budget friendly laptop (if you use mostly web apps) or tablet replacement. Especially if you're someone who does a lot of typing and isn't a fan of doing it on tablet screens!

I don't use it much myself, but I've talked with the recipient extensively, and this is a summary of their thoughts. They're a professional video editor who uses this as a supplemental portable computer when traveling, or just around the house where the have wi-fi and don't want to be chained to a serious editing station computer.

Form: This is a compact, sexy looking laptop. Although it's plastic, it's well built, slim, and finished to look like brushed aluminum. Very nice. Notably, the keyboard is a full sized for normal human hands. I sort of expected it to feel cramped, but it feels normal sized and eminently usable.

Specs: Screen is 1366-by-768 (16:9) so while you won't be able to view full 1080p video, 720 video looks great though. Dual Core processor w/ 2gb ram made web browsing with numerous tabs open quite snappy. Performance does drop off a bit if you're one of those crazy people who has to have 20 or 30 or 40+ tabs open at the same time. Camera is unequivocally made for things like skype, not for taking high-def pictures, but it suits its purpose just fine. For ports, you've got one each of USB 2.0, USB 3.0, and HDMI, so you can connect a mouse if you want or link it up to your TV for streaming HD video! There is a card reader for SD/SDHC/SDXC and audio has a mic input and headphone output. Local storage is somewhat compact at 16gb, but this is compensated by google drive access (100gb free for two years!) and can be supplemented by dropbox, amazon cloud, skydrive, etc.

Web Apps: The giftee already lived extensively in the google web-app environment so they jumped right in! When I purchased it, this came with two years of 100gb google drive storage. Pretty cool. Otherwise web apps and such work just the way you expect them to work.

Overall: If you want a super portable and very stylish laptop, you're comfortable working in the google environment of web apps, you have ready access to wi-fi, and you're on a budget so you don't want to shell out ~$1000 for a mac air, this is a fantastic product.

Negatives:
1) You really need to have wi-fi access to use this most effectively. Evaluate your wi-fi accessibility carefully before you take the plunge, and note that your local storage is limited to 16gb. Without that extra 100gb of google drive, or access to your dropbox/amazon cloud/skydrive you can easily feel the constrained.
2) There is no support for netflix. Presently, every chromebook EXCEPT for this one (Samsung, ARM based) can stream netflix. Hulu and Amazon streaming both work fine but this is a pretty glaring negative for folks who are thinking about a chromebook for its portability and access to web apps.

EDIT:

The Samsung Chromebook now supports netflix streaming. I'll leave the original review for posterity, but negative #2 is effectively removed. I don't think it bumps this chromebook up to a 5th star, as negative #1 still stands, but it's a very nice improvement, and I'm very glad that google/samsung kept their commitment to netflix support!

I wasn't going to delete them because Google's unstable, bug-ridden operating system can't handle them.  So I returned it.

Don't expect smooth sailing from your Chromebook.  Google is likely years away from putting out a stable Chrome OS.  You also shouldn't expect any support from Google, who make no effort at communicating with customers.  Samsung support is slightly better.  But they can only resolve hardware issues.  The awful operating system is all Google's fault.

Update: Before I returned it today, I made one last attempt at fixing the browser crashes.  I did a reset to the original factory settings.  Then I opened a session in Guest mode.  In this mode, there were no extraneous extensions, addons, plugins, or apps.  I was running the OS exactly as Google released it.  I browsed Google News for a miraculous 20 minutes.  I thought all was well, but then it crashed again.

To the people who find this review "unhelpful," I sincerely hope your experience with this product goes better than mine.  Maybe my Chromebook is just a lemon.  But if you search the web for Chromebook crashes, you'll find lots of discussions on Google product support as well as other forums.  There are many users who share my frustration.  It's disconcerting that Google and Samsung support can provide no other troubleshooting steps other than clearing cookies or performing a factory reset.  Again, the core problem is a buggy OS that's not ready for prime time.

Buyer beware.

The Samsung chromebook is a solid accessory for laptop users who want a lightweight alternative that provides more functionality than most tablets and smartphones.  The only thing to keep in mind is that this is a connected product that depends on a connection to the Google online services to be useful.

I purchased this unit and the Acer Chromebook to assess its use as a supplementary computer for consultants traveling with our company.  My criteria for a good alternative would be based on:
-Ability to access and use web applications used by our consultants
-Ease of use for a non-technical user
-Portability
-Reliability
-Durability

Chrome OS:  The chrome OS, the interface and the operation of the software on both the Samsung and the Acer are identical.  Setup of the software takes about 5 minutes if you don't have a google account and about 2 minutes if you do.  Be aware that all new Google Accounts are automatically also signed up for Google+.  While I like Google+ some may not want to join yet another social network.  Unfortunately I don't see a way to opt out of that registration at the present time.

Since the Chrome OS relies so heavily on the Google internet presence for almost all functionality, Google gives you a 2 year, 100 gb account on Google Drive to use with your Chrome OS (and your other computers).  It is on the G Drive that you will store all the files that you will use with the Chrome OS.  There is a limited 16gb of local storage on the device, but it is sometimes tough to see the distinction between the online/local file locations.  Best to store most files online.

Booting the Chrome OS from a complete power off state takes a very quick 7-10 seconds on both the Acer and the Samsung.  ChromeOS logon is with your Google account credentials.  From credential logon to the desktop is less than a second.  If you use the Chrome browser on your laptop or desktop PC and have it sync'd with your Google account, you will bring all the "apps", bookmarks, extensions and history to the ChromeOS.  Setup of the desktop is straightforward and shouldn't confuse too many modern OS users.  Communications setup is also easy for wifi.  Bluetooth is available on the Samsung but requires delving into the "settings" options.  Applications, the Chrome Browser and other functions are arranged on the bottom left of the screen and pull up using the touchpad.  If you have used the Chrome Browser, GMail or other Google Apps, then you will be right at home on the OS.  I won't spend much time on the Google apps as this is a hardware review, but they work relatively well.  Google Docs, Sheets, Slides, Gmail, Calendar and GDrive can all read and write standard office formats.  In my experience they can adequately replace MS office for on the go work and editing.  More complex editing and design is still best left to the more robust office tools.

The Chrome OS is put into sleep if you close the screen and wakes to your last desktop when opened.  However, it does not appear that a relogon is forced after wake, leaving all of your data from the previous session up with your credentials. The Acer will sleep for approximately 24 hours while the Samsung can sleep a couple of days.

Battery:  Battery life is much better on the Samsung with a full battery lasting about 7 hours under a good load.  The Acer battery is much weaker at 3 hours.  Samsung's battery is integrated into the laptop yielding a lighter weight and more refined look.  The acer battery is swappable but heavier.  Replacing the Samsung battery would require complete disassembly of the unit, much like the Macbook Airs or Iphones.

Speed:  The Samsung is powered by 2gb of RAM and the exynos 1.7ghz processor (2 cores).  The acer uses an intel celeron 1.1ghz CPU with 2 gb of memory.  Memory is upgradeable in the Acer to 4 gig.  Samsung is not upgradeable.  The Samsung handled all loads I put on it, including heavy browser use, VUDU/Hulu/YouTube streaming HD and SD video.  Likewise the Acer was able to handle the same.  Page access and switching between tabs was quick as was access to email and Google Apps.  The Graphics process on the Acer is the Intel HD which should outperform the Samsungs integrated ARM Mali-T604.  However, since neither machine is really for designed for graphics intensive work (games, video/photo editing, etc..), the performance difference between the two is not noticeable.

Storage:  The Samsung uses a very meager but fast 16gb of SSD storage, while the Acer uses a standard 320gb 5400rpm HD.  While the extra local storage is roomy, the Acer HD requires more power and cooling and this is noticeable in the shorter battery life.  The Acer also needs a fan to cool the HD and this can heat up the bottom of the laptop and further reduce battery life.  For an OS that requires the internet for use and storage, the larger Acer HD is superfluous.

Screen:  The Samsung and Acer both use a 11.6" screen.  Both screens are bright and viewable with auto adjusting (but defeatable) brightness.  The Samsung screen is slightly more viewable and bright.  The screen on the Samsung is angle constrained by its hinge with a full, flat recline not possible.  The Acers screen will lay flat if needed.

Keyboard:  The Samsung and Acer both have unlit keyboards with a standard QWERTY layout.  No number pad on either.  The samsung keys are very responsive, well positioned and have a good feel.  The Acer keyboard is less responsive and has a very cheap feel to it.

Touchpad:  Both the Samsung and Acer use touchpads for scrolling and clicking.  Right clicking is performed with a non-intuitive two finger touch/press.  The samsung touchpad is adequate and gives a decent feel of the desktop.  It does feel slightly sticky.  The Acer touchpad is less responsive and sometimes did not register movement.  A USB external mouse can be used on both.

Ports: The Samsung gives you 2 USB ports, one 2.0 and one 3.0 highspeed.  The Acer has 3 USB 2.0 ports.  The Samsung gives a HDMI out while the Acer has VGA and HDMI.  Both can accept SD cards.  The Acer has an etherent port (10/100).  The Samsung is wifi only, no ethernet port.  Both Wifi are a/b/g/n

Power: Both Chromebooks use powerbricks and grounded cables.  The Samsung has a smaller brick.  Samsung has the adapter port on the back while Acer has chosen a side port.  The rear location of the port for the Samsung is a drawback as it is sometimes a tighter fit when abutted to a wall or work area.

Webcam: The Acer has a HD webcam (1280 X 720).  The Samsung has a VGA resolution webcam (640 X 480)

Speakers: The Acer and Samsung have adequate speakers for personal listening.  Both have headphone ports.

Durability and reliability:  Having only used both for about a month, I can't give a good feel for long term durability.  However having used both out in travel, I will say that the Samsung seems to be the better and more polished platform.  It has withstood some drops overnight in sub freezing temps without any issues. It has a much tighter build and seems to be better able to holdup log term.

Weight and Size: The Acer is heavier (3.1 pounds) than the Samsung (2.4 pounds), thicker (Acer: 1.1 inch, Samsung: .7 inch) and less wide (Acer 11.2 inch, Samsung: 11.4 inch) and deep (Acer: 8inch, Samsung: 8.1 inch).  Overall the Samsung has a noticeably smaller footprint and weight, feeling more portable.

Printing: Neither the Samsung or the Acer can directly connect to a printer.  Each has the option of using google's CloudPrint to access printers via the network.  Setting up cloudprint can be complex for non-technical users.  An alternative is to use Google Apps to either save documents to the GDrive and print from a full size computer, or save them as PDFs and access the printouts as files.

Conclusion: For the additional $50 difference for my criteria I would recommend the Samsung Chromebook.  For the road warrior who wants a backup computing device that has a full keyboard the Samsung is a great choice.  It boots quickly, has a familiar interface and can do about 90% of what a full Windows/Mac laptop does at a fraction of the cost.  It is lightweight, has good battery life and works well as long as it has a internet connection.  I will be making a recommendation to get the Samsung Chromebooks for our consultants.

I received my Chromebook 4 days ago after a two week wait.  That isn't a bad wait for one of the top two or three selling computer items on Amazon, and it's worth the wait.  I bought it sight unseen, and I couldn't be any happier with my choice.

The Chromebook is essentially a non-touchscreen tablet with a keyboard.  It is what netbooks wanted to be but weren't.  It is roughly two inches wider, an inch deeper, and a quarter inch thicker than my first generation iPad and incredibly light with very similar styling.  The keyboard feels "right" - the keys are properly sized and spaced and have a natural movement.  There are a few differences that take some getting used to (no outdated caps lock key, for instance), but those are easily overcome.  I especially like the placement of the volume and brightness controls.  The touchpad is very nice - not large enough to get in the way, not too small, although it does not always register my fingers on the first touch.  The screen is bright enough to be seen even with the sun at my back.  The speakers are surprisingly decent and not too tinny with a touch of bass.

The battery life is very impressive - I used the Chromebook for all of my surfing, email, and posting for a day without having to recharge.  Whenever I stopped using the device I just closed the screen and it hibernated; when I raised the screen the machine awoke almost instantaneously.  I also like that I can completely lower the brightness of the screen to black - nice if I'm listening to audio and don't need to see what's on the screen.

The Chrome experience takes some getting used to.  Pretty much everything is treated like a webpage in the browser;  while there are plenty of items in the Chrome store, very few, if any, are actual applications that run on the machine itself.  I'm still trying to learn how to make my Drive documents available offline, and Google Docs has some differences when compared to Office, but these are to be expected.  There is a learning curve for some keyboard commands and touchpad gestures.  I find myself minimizing the browser instead of the font size at times, and I'm searching for the home button when I reach the bottom of a webpage, but these are minor differences from my usual experience.  I do miss the keyboard shortcut for switching tabs; perhaps I'm missing something.

My only complaint so far is that I wish the screen would fold 180 degrees.  When lounging on the couch with the device in my lap I'm tempted to push the screen too far back.  It isn't a major complaint by any stretch.

The Chromebook is a good device, but it is a great device for the money.  It seems like the perfect device to pair with a pico projector for sales presentations or for allowing the kids to watch videos while traveling.
